Object name: PHOTOGRAPH OF THE CHARLES MORRISON MEMORIAL.
Maker/Donor: Lent by A. P. Paton, Esq.
Object entry information: This is taken from a plaster cast commemorating the electric telegraph proposed in 1753 by "C.M."; believed by some to be Charles Morrison, an inhabitant of Renfrew. Other authorities identify the writer as Charles Marshall, who also, at one time lived at Renfrew. "C.M." suggested frictional electricity and a separate insulated wire for each symbol; the receiver noted the attraction by a ball attached to the wire, of a paper slip about $\frac{1}{8}$-in. below it, on which was the symbol.

Catalogue number: 2.
Object name: RONALDS’ ELECTROSTATIC TELEGRAPH.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: 1816
Object entry information: This is a specimen of the conductor, together with a model of the dial used by Sir Francis Ronalds on the experimental electric telegraph circuit in the garden of his house in the Upper Mall, Hammersmith, in 1816. He employed a frictional electric machine (see Cat. No. 3) to charge the line, and at each end had a pith-ball electroscope which collapsed when the line was discharged. At the two stations were dials revolved synchronously by clockwork; the dials were marked with the alphabet, but were masked by front plates that left only one letter visible. The sender discharged the line when he saw the desired letter, and the receiver noted the letter at which the pith-balls collapsed. By the use of a code, a word or even a whole sentence could be conveyed by two or three discharges. Ronalds made his first experiments through eight miles of overhead wire suspended by silk from hooks in horizontal bars. He then laid down his underground line :— “A trench was dug in the garden 525 ft. in length and 4 ft. deep ; in this was laid a trough of wood 2 in. sq., lining the inside of it with pitch, and in this trough tubes were placed through which the wires ran. The joints between the glass tubes were made with soft wax. The trough was then covered with pieces of wood screwed down upon it while the pitch was hot ; these also were well covered with pitch and the earth then thrown into the trench again.” Some of this line was dug up in 1862. The invention was brought to the notice of the Admiralty, but it was then deemed “wholly unnecessary,” and Ronalds seems to have gone no further with it. (20868)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1894-158. (20868)
title: Photo of Morrison memorial

Catalogue number: 4.
Object name: COPY OF SCHILLING'S ELECTRIC TELEGRAPH. Plate I.
Maker/Donor: Made by the British Telegraph Manufactory.
Date of creation: 1825–32
Object entry information: This is a copy of a portion of the telegraph, preserved in the Imperial Academy of Sciences, Petrograd, which was the outcome of experiments made by Baron P. L. Schilling in 1825–32. The receiver part of the instrument consists of a galvanometer with a horizontal needle suspended by a silken thread. The needle carries above it a disc of paper painted black on one side and white on the other; by the deflection of the needle to right or left, two primary signals were obtained. The instrument was made almost " dead beat " by a plate on the axis dipping into a bath of mercury beneath. The alarm call shown consists of a horizontal needle suspended in a coil and so arranged that when deflected by the passage of a current it strikes a trigger gear that releases the escapement of a clockwork alarm. The currents were first transmitted by placing the ends of the line wires in a bath of mercury, but afterwards a simple key was added.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1877-341.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 5.
Object name: TYPE USED FOR ORIGINAL MORSE TELEGRAPH.
Maker/Donor: Lent by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: 1835
Object entry information: These are relics of the electric telegraph devised by Prof. S. B. Morse and constructed by him in 1835. The transmitter consisted of a clockwork mechanism by means of which cast metal type, some of which are shown, were fed past a lever. The serrations on the edges of the type actuated the lever and thereby caused it to make intermittent contact in a pair of mercury cups. In the receiver an electro-magnetic arrangement caused a pen to make irregular V-shaped marks on a paper strip which was drawn past it by clockwork. These marks were interpreted as numbers which were arranged in a code-book. A model of the apparatus was worked through ten miles of insulated wire, wound upon two reels, in the year 1837.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1894-158A.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]

Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1894-158B.

Catalogue number: 7.
Object name: SIR W. F. COOKE'S ORIGINAL ELECTRIC ALARUM.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Institution of Electrical Engineers.
Date of creation: February, 1837
Object entry information: The alarum is set in motion by means of an electro-magnet. The armature on being actuated removes a detent and allows the clockwork to ring the bell. Finding that the alarum would not work reliably, through even one mile of wire, Sir W. F. Cooke consulted Sir Charles Wheatstone with a view to finding a remedy. This resulted in the invention of the Wheatstone relay, a delicate instrument, which by responding to feeble currents, closes a local battery circuit through the coils of the alarum electro-magnet, and permits of signalling over great distances. Developments of the relay are in use in nearly all modern telegraph systems. The first meeting of Wheatstone and Cooke took place in February, 1837, and led to the establishment of the partnership which extended over many years and proved so productive of new ideas in the progress of the electric telegraph.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923-278.
title: Cylinder electrical machine, 1810-1817
description: Cylinder electrical machine made by George John Singer, electrical researcher and lecturer at 3 Princes Street, Cavendish Square, London, England, 1810-1817.  Used by Sir Francis Ronalds (1788–1873), inventor and meteorologist at the Kew Observatory after 1843.

Object entry information: This is a copy of a portion of the telegraph, preserved in the Imperial Academy of Sciences, Petrograd, which was the outcome of experiments made by Baron P. L. Schilling in 1825–32. The receiver part of the instrument consists of a galvanometer with a horizontal needle suspended by a silken thread. The needle carries above it a disc of paper painted black on one side and white on the other; by the deflection of the needle to right or left, two primary signals were obtained. The instrument was made almost " dead beat " by a plate on the axis dipping into a bath of mercury beneath. The alarm call shown consists of a horizontal needle suspended in a coil and so arranged that when deflected by the passage of a current it strikes a trigger gear that releases the escapement of a clockwork alarm. The currents were first transmitted by placing the ends of the line wires in a bath of mercury, but afterwards a simple key was added.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1877-341.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 5.
Object name: TYPE USED FOR ORIGINAL MORSE TELEGRAPH.
Maker/Donor: Lent by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: 1835
Object entry information: These are relics of the electric telegraph devised by Prof. S. B. Morse and constructed by him in 1835. The transmitter consisted of a clockwork mechanism by means of which cast metal type, some of which are shown, were fed past a lever. The serrations on the edges of the type actuated the lever and thereby caused it to make intermittent contact in a pair of mercury cups. In the receiver an electro-magnetic arrangement caused a pen to make irregular V-shaped marks on a paper strip which was drawn past it by clockwork. These marks were interpreted as numbers which were arranged in a code-book. A model of the apparatus was worked through ten miles of insulated wire, wound upon two reels, in the year 1837.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1894-158A.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 6.
Object name: INSULATORS FOR MORSE TELEGRAPH.
Maker/Donor: Lent by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: 1835
Object entry information: These insulators were used by Prof. S. B. Morse for the telegraph which he constructed in 1835. A description of the apparatus which he employed will be found in the label which accompanies Cat. No. 5, "Type used for original Morse Telegraph."
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1894-158B.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 7.
Object name: SIR W. F. COOKE'S ORIGINAL ELECTRIC ALARUM.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Institution of Electrical Engineers.
Date of creation: February, 1837
Object entry information: The alarum is set in motion by means of an electro-magnet. The armature on being actuated removes a detent and allows the clockwork to ring the bell. Finding that the alarum would not work reliably, through even one mile of wire, Sir W. F. Cooke consulted Sir Charles Wheatstone with a view to finding a remedy. This resulted in the invention of the Wheatstone relay, a delicate instrument, which by responding to feeble currents, closes a local battery circuit through the coils of the alarum electro-magnet, and permits of signalling over great distances. Developments of the relay are in use in nearly all modern telegraph systems. The first meeting of Wheatstone and Cooke took place in February, 1837, and led to the establishment of the partnership which extended over many years and proved so productive of new ideas in the progress of the electric telegraph.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923-278.
title: Sir W. F. Cooke's original electric alarum, 1835-1840
description: Sir W. F. Cooke's original electric alarum, unknown maker, British, 1835-1840

Object entry information: This is a portion of the experimental telegraph line laid down between Euston and Camden Town by Messrs. Cooke & Wheatstone in 1837; the specimen was dug up about 30 years later. The arrangement consists of a wooden block of trapezoidal section, in the top and two sides of which five copper wires were inserted, in grooves containing a resinous material, and blocked up with strips of wood, the whole being afterwards coated with a protecting compound.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 9.
Object name: FIVE-NEEDLE INSTRUMENT.
Maker/Donor: Lent by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: 1837
Object entry information: This instrument was included in 1837 by Messrs. Cooke & Wheatstone in their first patent for improvements in giving signals by electric currents; a single-needle telegraph was, however, already known. Five galvanometers or magnetic needles and coils were used, arranged in a horizontal row on the vertical diamond-shaped dial; stops were placed to limit the deflection of the needles. Each needle was operated by a separate lever fitted with two finger keys, so arranged that a current could be sent in either direction. When signalling two needles were simultaneously deflected in opposite directions, the letter was indicated by the intersection of their centre lines on the dial and the point of intersection of their centre lines on the dial indicated the letter to be read off. Twenty letters could thus be signalled, and by employing the needles singly the ten numerals could be transmitted; these numerals were placed on the margins of the lower half of the dial. To obtain a closed circuit when the needles were used singly, a sixth lever and line wire were provided. The letters C, J, Q, U, X, and Z were not represented on the dial, other letters or combinations of letters being used instead. Plate 2.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876-1272.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 10.
Object name: DOUBLE-NEEDLE INSTRUMENT.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Reid Bros.
Date of creation: 1837
Object entry information: This is one of Messrs. Cooke & Wheatstone's instruments of 1837 which was used on the line between Paddington and Slough in 1842. In 1845 it created much interest through having secured the capture of a murderer. Owing to the frequent failure of one of the line wires, or of four or five-needle instruments, it was soon found by the operators that the alphabet could be formed by two needles only, if advantage were taken of repeated momentary deflections. The coils and needles are similar to those of the five-needle instrument, but the code was different, since the symbols were indicated by deflections of one or both of the needles; two line wires were used. An alarm which could be cut out by means of a handle at the side of the instrument was placed at the top. Plate 2.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876-1275.
title: Section of first telegraph cable, 1837
description: Piece of the original telegraph line laid down between Euston Square and Camden Town, made by William Cooke and Charles Wheatstone, England, 1837.

title: Cooke and Wheatstone double needle telegraph, 1844
description: Cooke and Wheatstone's double needle telegraph, invented by Sir William Fothergill Cooke (1806-1879) and Sir Charles Wheatstone (1802-1875), and made by William Reid, London, England, 1844.  This instrument was installed at Paddington when the experimental telegraph was extended to Slough in 1843.  On January 1, 1845 the Slough instrument sent a message to Paddington which enabled the identification and arrest of an alleged murderer.
material: brass (copper, zinc alloy); copper (alloy); wood (unidentified); silk
maker: Cooke, William Fothergill; Wheatstone, Sir Charles; Reid, William

Object entry information: This instrument (of the type introduced by Messrs. Cooke & Wheatstone in 1838), was used in 1846 at the Houses of Parliament. The case was designed in 1884 in the Gothic style in imitation of its surroundings.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 12
Object name: A B C TRANSMITTER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Reid Bros.
Date of creation: 1839 (designed by Sir W. F. Cooke); 1846 (patent).
Object entry information: This is one of the first of this type of instrument, having been designed by Sir W. F. Cooke in 1839; similar ones were tried on the Great Western Railway between Paddington and Slough. The instrument was included in Messrs. Cooke & Wheatstone's patent of 1846. There is a spring-driven clockwork train which actuates the pointer, controlled by an escapement worked by pallets which are a continuation of a hinged armature vibrating between two electro-magnets. The current is generated by rotating the outer rim of the dial by means of a knob (broken off); the rim gear drives two pinions each provided with two discs insulated by ivory and pressed on by springs, forming a make-and-break contact, but the machine is incomplete.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876-1418.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 13
Object name: EARLY ADVERTISEMENTS OF THE ELECTRIC TELEGRAPH. Plate 3.
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: 1845 (printed).
Object entry information: These are two handbills on one sheet, printed in 1845, announcing the exhibition to the public of Messrs. Cooke & Wheatstone's telegraph between Paddington and Slough. The statement that “The electric fluid travels at the rate of 280,000 miles per second,” was probably derived from a fallacious piece of reasoning by S. P. Thompson, (See “Elementary Lessons in Electricity and Magnetism,” by S. P. Thompson, p. 311).
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876-1350.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 14
Object name: SINGLE-NEEDLE INSTRUMENT.
Maker/Donor: Lent by J. A. Warwick, Esq.
Date of creation: 1846.
Object entry information: This early instrument is marked “W. F. Cooke invenit,” and was used by the Electric Telegraph Co. in 1846 on railway circuits. The code used closely resembles that of modern instruments, right- and left-hand movements of the needle being made by currents through a single line wire. It is fitted with the early crutch-handle commutator for transmitting.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876-1280.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 15
Object name: SPECIMEN OF EARLY UNDERGROUND TELEGRAPH CABLE LAID IN LONDON, 1846.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: 1846.
Object entry information: Each separate conductor is wrapped with cotton thread and coated with a mixture of tar, resin and grease. Nine wires are then packed in a 4-in. leaden pipe. It was usual to draw four or five of the cables so formed into a buried iron pipe of about 3-in. diameter. (See Lardner's “Museum of Science and Art,” Vol. III; “The Electric Telegraph,” Chapter II, pp. 143-4.) A specimen of the first experimental underground telegraph line is shown with Ronalds's apparatus. (See Cat. No. 2.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913-234.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 16
Object name: HENLEY AND FORSTER'S DOUBLE-NEEDLE TELEGRAPH.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: 1848 (patented).
Object entry information: This system, which requires no battery for its operation, was patented in 1848 by Messrs. W. F. Henley & T. Forster. It was used in this country by the Magnetic Telegraph Company. When one of the two pedal keys is depressed, an electro-magnet is partially rotated in close proximity to the poles of a powerful compound permanent magnet. This movement generates a momentary magneto-electric current which passes to line and operates the corresponding needle at both the sending and receiving stations. On releasing the key, it is restored to its former position by a strong spring, and by this reversed movement, another momentary current is transmitted, this time in a contrary direction. On the axis of each indicating needle, and parallel to it is a small permanent magnet which swings between the poles of a semicircular electro-magnet. The pulsation of current received from line causes the electro-magnet to deflect
Object/Inventory number: N/A

title: LLM-LINKED
description: The sources list components associated with a "portion of first underground cable laid in London," specifically "Two screws from a portion of first underground cable" (co8643088) and a "Display baseboard with metal plaque for portion of first underground cable" (co8006001),. Object entry information: This system, which requires no battery for its operation, was patented in 1848 by Messrs. W. F. Henley & T. Forster. It was used in this country by the Magnetic Telegraph Company. When one of the two pedal keys is depressed, an electro-magnet is partially rotated in close proximity to the poles of a powerful compound permanent magnet. This movement generates a momentary magneto-electric current which passes to line and operates the corresponding needle at both the sending and receiving stations. On releasing the key, it is restored to its former position by a strong spring, and by this reversed movement, another momentary current is transmitted, this time in a contrary direction. On the axis of each indicating needle, and parallel to it is a small permanent magnet which swings between the poles of a semicircular electro-magnet. The pulsation of current received from line causes the electro-magnet to deflect the permanent magnet, and the deflection is continued by the effect of the induced magnetism between the two. Each needle can only be deflected to one side of the vertical position, the motion being limited by two stops.

Maker/Donor: Lent by H.M. Postmaster-General.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 18.
Object name: HIGHTON'S SINGLE-NEEDLE INSTRUMENTS (two Receiving Dials).
Maker/Donor: Made by Reid. Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: 1848
Object entry information: These instruments show the receiving portions only of improved single-needle telegraphs patented by H. and E. Highton, in 1848. Within two circular coils of wire, joined in series, a light horseshoe permanent magnet is fitted to the spindle which carries the indicating needle. This arrangement renders the instrument very sensitive to weak currents and marks a distinct advance in the design of telegraph apparatus. The indicating needles are missing.
Object/Inventory number: 1913-223.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 19.
Object name: MORSE EMBOSSER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: about 1853
Object entry information: This instrument was used about 1853 by the Electric Telegraph Co. It supplanted Bain's chemical recorder, as it obviated the troublesome chemical preparation of the paper, but reading the embossed marks was found so fatiguing, that this instrument was in turn displaced by the ink-writer. A relay or local circuit is used to work the electro-magnet, whose armature is fitted to a horizontal lever, working between stops at one end and carrying a steel style at the other. When the armature is attracted downwards, the style is pressed upwards against a strip of paper drawn from a large reel by two friction rollers, set in motion by a train of clockwork. In the upper roller is a narrow groove into which the style presses the paper and, according to the time the armature is held down, embosses a dot or a dash.
Object/Inventory number: 1876-1290.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 20.
Object name: MORSE SOUNDER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by the Post Office.
Date of creation: 1874
Object entry information: This instrument was adopted by the British Post Office in 1874, but had previously been in use in America. It consists of an electro-magnet having a soft iron armature mounted on a lever which moves between stops. The armature is attracted on the passage of the current, in opposition to the pull of a spring, and each signal consists of two clicks, one as the armature descends when attracted and the other when it returns under the action of the spring, the interval between the two depending upon whether the signal is a dot or a dash. (See Prescott's " Electricity and the Electric Telegraph," 5th edition, p. 435.)
Object/Inventory number: 1911-17.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 21.
Object name: A B C RECEIVER.
Maker/Donor: Wheatstone Collection.
Date of creation: 1858
Object entry information: This instrument is described in Sir C. Wheatstone's patent No. 1241, of 1858, where it is claimed that it works with "currents of less energy" and "with greater steadiness, certainty, and rapidity" than previous instruments. The dial has symbols corresponding with the instrument with which it works. The pointer is fixed on a small escape-wheel of 15 teeth which is propelled by a hair-spring; the levers are attached to two small magnets fixed to an arbor vibrating between the pole pieces of two small electro-magnets. A button above the dial serves to adjust the pointer by hand, and in the lower part of the case is placed an alarm.
Object/Inventory number: 1884-114.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 22.
Object name: SIEMENS'S INKWRITER.
Maker/Donor: Made by Messrs. Siemens Bros. Lent by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: 1862
Object entry information: This instrument, made by Messrs. Siemens Bros., embodies their patent of 1862; it superseded the Morse embosser, owing to its sensitiveness to weak currents, and to the greater legibility of the marks made. It has in turn been superseded by various type-printing telegraphs.

Catalogue number: 18.
Object name: HIGHTON'S SINGLE-NEEDLE INSTRUMENTS (two Receiving Dials).
Maker/Donor: Made by Reid. Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: 1848
Object entry information: These instruments show the receiving portions only of improved single-needle telegraphs patented by H. and E. Highton, in 1848. Within two circular coils of wire, joined in series, a light horseshoe permanent magnet is fitted to the spindle which carries the indicating needle. This arrangement renders the instrument very sensitive to weak currents and marks a distinct advance in the design of telegraph apparatus. The indicating needles are missing.
Object/Inventory number: 1913-223.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 19.
Object name: MORSE EMBOSSER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: about 1853
Object entry information: This instrument was used about 1853 by the Electric Telegraph Co. It supplanted Bain's chemical recorder, as it obviated the troublesome chemical preparation of the paper, but reading the embossed marks was found so fatiguing, that this instrument was in turn displaced by the ink-writer. A relay or local circuit is used to work the electro-magnet, whose armature is fitted to a horizontal lever, working between stops at one end and carrying a steel style at the other. When the armature is attracted downwards, the style is pressed upwards against a strip of paper drawn from a large reel by two friction rollers, set in motion by a train of clockwork. In the upper roller is a narrow groove into which the style presses the paper and, according to the time the armature is held down, embosses a dot or a dash.
Object/Inventory number: 1876-1290.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 20.
Object name: MORSE SOUNDER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by the Post Office.
Date of creation: 1874
Object entry information: This instrument was adopted by the British Post Office in 1874, but had previously been in use in America. It consists of an electro-magnet having a soft iron armature mounted on a lever which moves between stops. The armature is attracted on the passage of the current, in opposition to the pull of a spring, and each signal consists of two clicks, one as the armature descends when attracted and the other when it returns under the action of the spring, the interval between the two depending upon whether the signal is a dot or a dash. (See Prescott's " Electricity and the Electric Telegraph," 5th edition, p. 435.)
Object/Inventory number: 1911-17.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 21.
Object name: A B C RECEIVER.
Maker/Donor: Wheatstone Collection.

Object entry information: This instrument is described in Sir C. Wheatstone's patent No. 1241, of 1858, where it is claimed that it works with "currents of less energy" and "with greater steadiness, certainty, and rapidity" than previous instruments. The dial has symbols corresponding with the instrument with which it works. The pointer is fixed on a small escape-wheel of 15 teeth which is propelled by a hair-spring; the levers are attached to two small magnets fixed to an arbor vibrating between the pole pieces of two small electro-magnets. A button above the dial serves to adjust the pointer by hand, and in the lower part of the case is placed an alarm.
Object/Inventory number: 1884-114.

title: Wheatstone's portable ABC telegraph
description: Wheatstone's ABC telegraph receiver, England, 1858.

Maker/Donor: Made by Messrs. Siemens Bros. Lent by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Object entry information: This instrument, made by Messrs. Siemens Bros., embodies their patent of 1862; it superseded the Morse embosser, owing to its sensitiveness to weak currents, and to the greater legibility of the marks made. It has in turn been superseded by various type-printing telegraphs. The form shown is supplied with a signalling key and galvanometer, and was used on lines of moderate length where a relay was not required. The armature of the electro-magnet is attached to a hinged lever working between stops; when no current is passing, it is brought to the upper position by a spring. A plain disc, fixed to a continuation of the hinged lever, lies behind the paper tape, from a horizontal reel contained in a drawer in the base of the instrument, is carried between friction rollers worked by a clock-train controlled by a governor, the train also revolving the inking disc. When the armature is attracted the inking disc is thrown into contact with the paper strip, and, according to the duration of the current, registers a dot or dash. All the parts can be regulated by screw adjustments.

Object entry information: This was the earliest form of acoustic instrument introduced into Great Britain, where it was used by the British and Irish Magnetic Telegraph Co. Two plates or bells of different tones are used to produce a code by means of sound. The hammers are fixed to the armatures of two electro-magnets, the relay which works being pivoted on a magnetised rod enclosed in a coil. The coils consists of two thin permanent magnets placed side by side, their poles being furnished with pole pieces turning inwards. Between these vibrate the ends of two slightly magnetised levers pivoted on vertical axes, the poles of the magnets being so placed that a current in one direction attracts a magnet which closes the local circuit of the right-hand bell and the current in the opposite direction attracts the other magnet which closes the local circuit of the left-hand bell. The pedal or tapper-key is used to send the signals.

A plain disc, fixed to a continuation of the hinged lever, lies behind the paper tape, from a horizontal reel contained in a drawer in the base of the instrument, is carried between friction rollers worked by a clock-train controlled by a governor, the train also revolving the inking disc. Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 24.
Object name: ORIGINAL NEALE SOUNDER.
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This instrument was devised for the purpose of enabling the telegraph operator to read the signals of the single needle code by sound, instead of by sight, thereby making it a more rapid system. The heavy soft iron needle strikes on metal pins attached to the wooden sides of the case. In later patterns, split metal tubes are used to increase the acoustic properties of the dial. Developments of the Neale sounder are shown in adjacent positions. The sending portion of the apparatus consists of a double tapper commutator, similar to that used for single-needle instruments. (See also Bright's Bell Instrument and Relay, Inv. No. 1876–1286.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919–246.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 25.
Object name: SINGLE-NEEDLE INSTRUMENT. Plate 2.
Maker/Donor: Lent by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is a typical example of the drop-handle single needle used by railway companies. The receiving portion is of the Varley pattern, in which two bar magnets are used to magnetise inductively a light horseshoe of soft iron, fixed to the spindle of the indicating needle, and capable of turning to the right or left interiorly, according to the direction of the current.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1911–15.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 26.
Object name: NEALE SOUNDER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This instrument is a later development of the original pattern of Neale's Sounder (Cat. No. 24.). The electrical part of the apparatus consists of an electro-magnet, with extensions of its soft-iron pole-pieces brought through the dial. Between the pole-pieces is a pivoted piece of thick soft iron, the upper part of which is rendered magnetic by induction from an angular permanent magnet, placed behind the dial. The sounder strikes with stiff wire extensions, projecting horizontally, upon which the needle strikes. The milled screw below the dial is for the purpose of adjusting the needle to the central position. The instrument has been partially sectioned to show the arrangement of the permanent and electro-magnets.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913–219.

Maker/Donor: Lent by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is a typical example of the drop-handle single needle used by railway companies. The receiving portion is of the Varley pattern, in which two bar magnets are used to magnetise inductively a light horseshoe of soft iron, fixed to the spindle of the indicating needle, and capable of turning to the right or left interiorly, according to the direction of the current.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1911–15.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 26.
Object name: NEALE SOUNDER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This instrument is a later development of the original pattern of Neale's Sounder (Cat. No. 24.). The electrical part of the apparatus consists of an electro-magnet, with extensions of its soft-iron pole-pieces brought through the dial. Between the pole-pieces is a pivoted piece of thick soft iron, the upper part of which is rendered magnetic by induction from an angular permanent magnet, placed behind the dial. The sounder strikes with stiff wire extensions, projecting horizontally, upon which the needle strikes. The milled screw below the dial is for the purpose of adjusting the needle to the central position. The instrument has been partially sectioned to show the arrangement of the permanent and electro-magnets.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913–219.

Catalogue number: N/A
Object name: N/A
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The form shown is supplied with a signalling key and galvanometer, and was used on lines of moderate length where a relay was not required. The armature of the electro-magnet is attached to a hinged lever working between stops; when no current is passing, it is brought to the upper position by a spring. A plain disc, fixed to a continuation of the hinged lever, lies behind the paper tape, from a horizontal reel contained in a drawer in the base of the instrument, is carried between friction rollers worked by a clock-train controlled by a governor, the train also revolving the inking disc. When the armature is attracted the inking disc is thrown into contact with the paper strip, and, according to the duration of the current, registers a dot or dash. All the parts can be regulated by screw adjustments.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876–1291.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 23.
Object name: BRIGHT'S BELL INSTRUMENT AND RELAY.
Maker/Donor: Lent by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This was the earliest form of acoustic instrument introduced into Great Britain, where it was used by the British and Irish Magnetic Telegraph Co. Two plates or bells of different tones are used to produce a code by means of sound. The hammers are fixed to the armatures of two electro-magnets, the relay which works being pivoted on a magnetised rod enclosed in a coil. The coils consists of two thin permanent magnets placed side by side, their poles being furnished with pole pieces turning inwards. Between these vibrate the ends of two slightly magnetised levers pivoted on vertical axes, the poles of the magnets being so placed that a current in one direction attracts a magnet which closes the local circuit of the right-hand bell and the current in the opposite direction attracts the other magnet which closes the local circuit of the left-hand bell. The pedal or tapper-key is used to send the signals.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876–1286.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 24.
Object name: ORIGINAL NEALE SOUNDER.
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This instrument was devised for the purpose of enabling the telegraph operator to read the signals of the single needle code by sound, instead of by sight, thereby making it a more rapid system. The heavy soft iron needle strikes on metal pins attached to the wooden sides of the case. In later patterns, split metal tubes are used to increase the acoustic properties of the dial. Developments of the Neale sounder are shown in adjacent positions. The sending portion of the apparatus consists of a double tapper commutator, similar to that used for single-needle instruments. (See also Bright's Bell Instrument and Relay, Inv. No. 1876–1286.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919–246.

Object entry information: This instrument is designed to work either as a single needle or as a single current Morse sounder. By a sliding movement of the two brass studs on the front of the dial, the needle may be either centred between the split tubes, in which condition it is suitable for single needle working, or it may be adjusted to rest normally on the left-hand pin, in which case the needle acts as a sounder armature and responds to Morse signals sent from a single current key.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 28.
Object name: EBEL SOUNDER WITH STYLOGRAPH.
Maker/Donor: Made and presented by Messrs. Siemens Bros. & Co.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This compact telegraph set enables the sender to take a carbon copy of the transmitted message from the signals actually sent. The style is a single current Morse key and when held as a pencil, with the white stud uppermost, pressure of the point on the paper closes a circuit connecting the battery to line. In practice, therefore, the message is written and signalled at the same time in Morse code. When not in use for sending, the style joins the line to one end of an electro-magnet coil, the other end of which is connected to earth. The coil works on a pivoted arm and is lightly held against a limiting stop by a spiral spring. When a current passes through the windings, the coil turns downward on its pivots and the metal ends of the core strike on an iron plate, thus giving the characteristic click of a sounder. A small compass needle, supported near the coil, acts as a galvanometer by electro-magnetic induction.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–515.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 29.
Object name: FIELD INKER.
Maker/Donor: Made by Messrs. Siemens & Halske. Presented by Messrs. Siemens Bros. & Co.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is a portable field inker telegraph set used by the German army. A small Morse key is hinged to the outer case and when not in use is turned to lie in a recess where it is covered by a leather flap. The receiver is of the start-stop type and when set in motion by the distant station an alarm on a single stroke bell is given at frequent intervals. A small drawer in the base of the case carries the roll of paper tape.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–512.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 30.
Object name: THE FULLERPHONE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The War Office.
Date of creation: invented during the war of 1914–18.
Object entry information: This instrument, which was invented by Major A. C. Fuller, R.E., was extensively used during the war of 1914–18. Under ideal conditions, the apparatus is so sensitive that it will operate with a current of less than half a micro-ampere. On field lines, where heavy leakage is frequently experienced, the system is superior to other methods of line telegraphy. It possesses the outstanding advantage that the weak direct current traversing the circuit does not produce noticeable inductive effects in adjacent wires and it is almost impossible for a Fullerphone circuit to be “tapped.” At the receiving station the signals are passed through an interrupter which renders them suitable for reception on a telephone receiver. The Fullerphone may also be superposed on telephone circuits so that both telegraph and telephone services work simultaneously without the one interfering with the other.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–195.

title: Fullerphone, P.O. pattern 237A, 1916-1918
description: Fullerphone, Post Office (P.O.) pattern 237A.  Fullerphones P.O. Types Marks 237, 237a and 273b were produced by the Post Office during the First World War, from 1916 onwards.

Object entry information: This receiver was used by the Electric Telegraph Co. (1850) to replace the double-needle instrument. It is now only in use for experimental purposes, but is so rapid and sensitive in its action that it may again come into favour. A strip of paper is drawn off a small gutta-percha bobbin placed inside a short brass cylinder, and over a drum whose surface is silvered; the latter is rotated by a clockwork train having a fan brake. The clockwork is started or stopped by a small lever working between two stops and when in the stopping position makes contact with the earth terminal. A small wooden roller is pushed into contact with the silvered drum to keep the paper stretched and against which it is kept pressed down to the paper. The style (missing) is a piece of iron or steel and is in connection with the line wire terminal, while the drum is in connection with the earth terminal. The paper tape was soaked in a mixture of one volume of a saturated solution of potassium ferrocyanide, one volume of a saturated solution of ammonium nitrate, and two volumes of water; the latter salt, being deliquescent, served to keep the paper damp. When a current passes, the iron decomposes the electrolyte, uniting the acid radical to form Prussian blue; other solutions, such as potassium iodide, can be used, the iodine liberated from which colours a starch solution. The Steilheil code, (dots in two parallel lines) was originally used but was entirely superseded by the Morse. Inv. 1888–198–9.

It is now only in use for experimental purposes, but is so rapid and sensitive in its action that it may again come into favour. A strip of paper is drawn off a small gutta-percha bobbin placed inside a short brass cylinder, and over a drum whose surface is silvered; the latter is rotated by a clockwork train having a fan brake. The clockwork is started or stopped by a small lever working between two stops and when in the stopping position makes contact with the earth terminal. A small wooden roller is pushed into contact with the silvered drum to keep the paper stretched and against which it is kept pressed down to the paper. The style (missing) is a piece of iron or steel and is in connection with the line wire terminal, while the drum is in connection with the earth terminal. The paper tape was soaked in a mixture of one volume of a saturated solution of potassium ferrocyanide, one volume of a saturated solution of ammonium nitrate, and two volumes of water; the latter salt, being deliquescent, served to keep the paper damp. When a current passes, the iron decomposes the electrolyte, uniting the acid radical to form Prussian blue; other solutions, such as potassium iodide, can be used, the iodine liberated from which colours a starch solution. The Steilheil code, (dots in two parallel lines) was originally used but was entirely superseded by the Morse. Inv. 1888–198–9.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1888–198–9.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 32.
Object name: TYPE-PRINTING TELEGRAPH.
Maker/Donor: Lent by J. W. Brett, Esq.
Date of creation: 1845
Object entry information: This telegraph was patented by Mr. Jacob Brett in 1845, as a communication from Mr. R. E. House, of New York. The instruments shown are those by which the first messages through the submarine cable from Dover to Cape Gris Nez were transmitted, in 1851. The transmitter has 40 buttons or keys, but there are only 29 different symbols, as the commoner ones are repeated. The keys are in two straight lines and when depressed engage with pins disposed in a single helix on the surface of a cylinder, rotated by bevel friction wheels, controlled by a continuously running fly. Fixed to the end of the cylinder is a commutator pressing upon two straight lines in the line circuit by which intermittent currents are sent to line when the wheel is released, the cylinder starts revolving at its full speed. In the receiver is a type-wheel, with the same number of symbols in the same order as in the transmitter, rotated by spring-driven wheelwork. A flier arm on the axis of the type-wheel engages with a tooth on the armature lever of an electro-magnet attracted by the intermittent currents. The type-wheel is further controlled by a ratchet wheel, the pawl of which can only move slowly, being attached to a dash-pot. The paper tape is advanced by a separate train of wheels which also give motion, whenever the type-wheel stops, to a pad wheel. The paper tape is advanced by eccentrics which move the plate up to the type. Inking is done by a roller. A call alarm is struck at every revolution on the eccentrics, but is secured by a hook when the instrument is in use. Inv. 1862–149.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1862–149.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 33.
Object name: HUGHES'S TYPE-PRINTING INSTRUMENT. Plate 4.
Maker/Donor: Lent by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: 1855
Object entry information: This instrument was invented by Prof. D. E. Hughes in 1855, for recording in roman type the message transmitted. It is much used on the Continent, but did not at first meet with such favour in this country, on account of its cost. The instrument differs from the other type-printers in being almost entirely mechanical; both sender and transmitter are identical in construction and action of the printing signals, synchronism being secured by the correcting action of the printing signals. On a piano keyboard are 26 keys, each with two symbols on it, which correspond with raised type on the periphery of the type-wheel; there are also two blank-space and change-case keys. When a key is depressed, one of the pins on the circumference of a circular plate is raised and catches a “chariot” geared with the type-wheel so closing the circuit. The gearing is so arranged that when the type-wheel is stopped by the pin the symbol corresponding to the key is opposite to the printing hammer. The current causes the paper at both stations to be lifted up into contact with the type, and at the same time an electro-magnet releases the detent in the gearing which drives the hammer. The gearing also causes the paper to move forward a space to be ready for the next symbol. The electrical arrangement is very simple; the

Object entry information: This instrument was invented by Prof. D. E. Hughes in 1855, for recording in roman type the message transmitted. It is much used on the Continent, but did not at first meet with such favour in this country, on account of its cost. The instrument differs from the other type-printers in being almost entirely mechanical; both sender and transmitter are identical in construction and action of the printing signals, synchronism being secured by the correcting action of the printing signals. On a piano keyboard are 26 keys, each with two symbols on it, which correspond with raised type on the periphery of the type-wheel; there are also two blank-space and change-case keys. When a key is depressed, one of the pins on the circumference of a circular plate is raised and catches a “chariot” geared with the type-wheel so closing the circuit. The gearing is so arranged that when the type-wheel is stopped by the pin the symbol corresponding to the key is opposite to the printing hammer. The current causes the paper at both stations to be lifted up into contact with the type, and at the same time an electro-magnet releases the detent in the gearing which drives the hammer. The gearing also causes the paper to move forward a space to be ready for the next symbol. The electrical arrangement is very simple; the current which is sent so weakens the polarity of an induced magnet as to cause it to release an armature under spring pressure; the armature is replaced by a cam. The instrument is sensitive to very weak currents, owing to the close balance that can be secured by adjusting the spring.

Object entry information: Automatic transmitters are instruments for sending into a line wire by mechanical means the irregular sequence of currents representing a message. Several operators may be employed preparing the messages for the transmitter, which then forwards them at a speed which is restricted only by the mechanical limits of the receiving instrument. The instruments, which are fully described in Sir C. Wheatstone's patent No. 1239, A.D. 1858, are intended to transmit currents from a battery. In the first two, a handle, driven by spur gearing, drives a fly-wheel and a crank which reciprocates a small frame, through which passes a tape having the message on it as a series of holes punched by a perforating instrument. On this frame is a spring clip which holds the paper during one swing of the frame but is raised during the return movement. There are three wires on the reciprocating frame, held up by light helical springs so that a slight and pressure is capable of keeping them depressed. "The middle wire only acts as a guide to the paper during the cessation of the currents," while the two outside wires are provided with contact-makers, by which a current is sent to line in one direction when one wire is elevated and in the opposite direction by the other. The third instrument closely resembles these but is intended for transmitting unreversed currents only.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 35.
Object name: PUNCHER FOR AUTOMATIC TELEGRAPH.
Maker/Donor: Presented. Wheatstone Collection.
Date of creation: 1867
Object entry information: This instrument is designed for perforating the strip of paper or "tape," used in automatic transmitters. The first puncher, by Sir C. Wheatstone (patent No. 1239, A.D. 1858) perforated the tape in two parallel lines representing the signals, while a central line of holes indicated the spaces between letters and words. The code used was a modification of Steinheil’s (1836), in which the number of holes in succession on either side of the central line was limited to four. In this instrument, patented by Sir C. Wheatstone in 1867, the tape is punched with a uniform line of central apertures, the signals as before being indicated by side perforations. There are three keys fixed to bell-crank levers, lifted by springs and each controlling a punch. The tape from a reel is drawn down a vertical groove by means of a small disc and lever worked from the central key-lever. The outside key-levers punch the side holes representing the symbols and by a projection on the centre key depressed it also. The latter is depressed independently for the spaces between letters and words.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1884-148.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 36.
Object name: TYPE-PRINTING TELEGRAPHS.
Maker/Donor: Lent by H.M. Post-master-General.
Date of creation: 1861
Object entry information: These are step-by-step instruments, patented by Mr. M. Theiler in 1861, and the transmitter resembles Wheatstone’s later A B C instruments, and has 28 keys arranged round a circular horizontal dial. The end of each key lever enters a circular ring provided with inclined notches; when a key is depressed it is kept down by the ring, but when a second key is touched that ring is slightly moved, so releasing the other key and locking the second one. Depressing a key also releases a wheel on a spring-driven train, which allows the pointer to travel round till stopped by the key lever; the axis of the pointer carries a commutator which sends to the line wire a reversed current for every letter that the pointer passes. In the receiver a type-wheel, on the axis of an escapement actuated by a spring-driven drum wound up by the printing mechanism, is controlled by spring-driven currents. Printing is performed by a spring-driven train liberated by an electro-magnet on a local battery circuit, closed by a vibratory arrangement which acts when the type-wheel stops.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876-1305.

Object entry information: Automatic transmitters are instruments for sending into a line wire by mechanical means the irregular sequence of currents representing a message. Several operators may be employed preparing the messages for the transmitter, which then forwards them at a speed which is restricted only by the mechanical limits of the receiving instrument. The instruments, which are fully described in Sir C. Wheatstone's patent No. 1239, A.D. 1858, are intended to transmit currents from a battery. In the first two, a handle, driven by spur gearing, drives a fly-wheel and a crank which reciprocates a small frame, through which passes a tape having the message on it as a series of holes punched by a perforating instrument. On this frame is a spring clip which holds the paper during one swing of the frame but is raised during the return movement. There are three wires on the reciprocating frame, held up by light helical springs so that a slight and pressure is capable of keeping them depressed. "The middle wire only acts as a guide to the paper during the cessation of the currents," while the two outside wires are provided with contact-makers, by which a current is sent to line in one direction when one wire is elevated and in the opposite direction by the other. The third instrument closely resembles these but is intended for transmitting unreversed currents only.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1884-135-6 and 8.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 35.
Object name: PUNCHER FOR AUTOMATIC TELEGRAPH.
Maker/Donor: Presented. Wheatstone Collection.
Date of creation: 1867
Object entry information: This instrument is designed for perforating the strip of paper or "tape," used in automatic transmitters. The first puncher, by Sir C. Wheatstone (patent No. 1239, A.D. 1858) perforated the tape in two parallel lines representing the signals, while a central line of holes indicated the spaces between letters and words. The code used was a modification of Steinheil’s (1836), in which the number of holes in succession on either side of the central line was limited to four. In this instrument, patented by Sir C. Wheatstone in 1867, the tape is punched with a uniform line of central apertures, the signals as before being indicated by side perforations. There are three keys fixed to bell-crank levers, lifted by springs and each controlling a punch. The tape from a reel is drawn down a vertical groove by means of a small disc and lever worked from the central key-lever. The outside key-levers punch the side holes representing the symbols and by a projection on the centre key depressed it also. The latter is depressed independently for the spaces between letters and words.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1884-148.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 36.
Object name: TYPE-PRINTING TELEGRAPHS.
Maker/Donor: Lent by H.M. Post-master-General.
Date of creation: 1861
Object entry information: These are step-by-step instruments, patented by Mr. M. Theiler in 1861, and the transmitter resembles Wheatstone’s later A B C instruments, and has 28 keys arranged round a circular horizontal dial. The end of each key lever enters a circular ring provided with inclined notches; when a key is depressed it is kept down by the ring, but when a second key is touched that ring is slightly moved, so releasing the other key and locking the second one. Depressing a key also releases a wheel on a spring-driven train, which allows the pointer to travel round till stopped by the key lever; the axis of the pointer carries a commutator which sends to the line wire a reversed current for every letter that the pointer passes. In the receiver a type-wheel, on the axis of an escapement actuated by a spring-driven drum wound up by the printing mechanism, is controlled by spring-driven currents. Printing is performed by a spring-driven train liberated by an electro-magnet on a local battery circuit, closed by a vibratory arrangement which acts when the type-wheel stops.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876-1305.
title: Theiler's step by step type printer transmitter
description: Theiler's step by step type printer transmitter, 1863-64

Object entry information: This is a modification of the telegraph patented in 1863-4 by Mons. P. A. J. Dujardin; the instrument was used by the Electric Telegraph Co. during 1865 on the line between London and Edinburgh. The receiver and transmitter are identical. There is a piano keyboard of 28 keys, each of which by a lever raises a pin in the periphery of a circular plate and catches an arm kept revolving by the treadle-wheel below. On the same shaft is a 14-wave face cam which causes a lever to vibrate between stops and sends reversals of the current to line to release the escapement of the type-wheel step by step. A polarised relay and local battery are used to work the wheelwork and prolong the action on the anchor at the extremity of any particular oscillation; this closes the local circuit of an electro-magnet which does the printing. An electro-magnetic device causes the printing currents to be equal in duration whether a key is held down for a long or a short interval of time. Inking is done by a pad.

Catalogue number: 38
Object name: PERFORATOR FOR AUTOMATIC TELEGRAPH.
Maker/Donor: Wheatstone Collection.
Date of creation: 1867 (patent date)
Object entry information: This perforator is described in Sir C. Wheatstone’s patent of 1867. It has three keys with rubber buffers, which are struck by small hand stamps, held one in each hand, so that the work of punching is done by the arms instead of by the fingers. There are five punches so arranged that the right-hand key punches three holes, the left-hand key three holes, while the central key punches a single hole. The paper is fed through by a roller and a roughened lever, which is moved when any of the three key levers is depressed.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1884-151.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 39
Object name: TYPE-PRINTING RECEIVER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by T. A. Edison, Esq.
Date of creation: 1872 (patented)
Object entry information: This instrument, patented in this country in 1872 by Mr. Edison, is for printing in roman characters on paper tape; it was originally intended for transmitting stock exchange prices, a large number of these receivers being actuated simultaneously by currents from one central transmitter. The receiver shown is the original apparatus, but is incomplete. The instrument is mounted on a hollow cast-iron base which contains two horse-shoe electro-magnets, one of which vibrates a lever that presses the tape upon the type-wheel, and at the same time feeds it through the machine; the other magnet vibrates a lever which carries a pawl that rotates the type-wheel by a step-by-step motion. The roll of tape is supported by arms above the instrument and the inking of the type is performed by a roller. By the use of polarised armatures, a single wire with reversed currents works the two electro-magnets as required.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1880-69.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 40
Object name: RECEIVER FOR BAUDOT MULTIPLEX TYPE-PRINTING TELEGRAPH.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Automatic Telephone Manufacturing Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1874-5 (invented)
Object entry information: This important system was invented by J. M. E. Baudot, a French Telegraph Engineer, in 1874-5. Only the receiver is shown. The Baudot multiplex is extensively used in this country, being worked under simplex conditions designed by Mr. A. C. Booth, of the Post Office Engineering Department, in 1905. By this method, it is not unusual for 8, 10 or even 12 telegrams to be in process of transmission over a single circuit at the same time. The type wheel is kept constantly revolving, a small electric motor being externally fitted for the purpose. The five relays at the top of the apparatus select the symbol to be printed, in accordance with the signals sent from the distant station. By mechanical means, the paper tape is flicked into contact with the type-wheel immediately the required character is in position for printing. The Baudot Multiplex telegraph is described in Herbert’s “Telegraphy,” 1920 edition, pp. 455-479. Other multiplex telegraph apparatus will be found exhibited under Cat. No. 41, Baudot Multiplex distribution plate, Cat. No. 43, Delany multiplex distributor plate.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1925-85.

Object entry information:
This is a modern sending plate, of French pattern, designed for use on a Baudot quadruple telegraph set.
Revolving brushes of flexible metal sweep over the surfaces of the rings in pairs. For instance, the second ring, consisting of 24 segments, may be joined through a pair of brushes to the continuous ring number 5, which is connected to line. In this way each keyboard is in contact with the line for a fraction of a second at frequent intervals. A separate distributor plate, of slightly different construction, is required for receiving. All the brushes are, however, carried on a common spindle which passes through the central aperture of both plates.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 42.
Object name: WRITING TELEGRAPH.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. E. A. & C. E. Cowper.
Date of creation: 1878
Object entry information: The experimental transmitter and receiver are shown, together with specimens of the writing and a diagram of the general arrangement. The instruments were invented by Mr. E. A. Cowper in 1878, and have worked successfully through a resistance of 1,000 ohms.
Two line wires are used, one of which transmits a current proportional to the vertical and the other to the horizontal displacement of the transmitter’s pen from its central position. This is accomplished by having attached to this pen two jointed rods which transmit the two components of the motion to contact pieces that slide over resistance frames arranged at right angles. These frames are built up of insulated plates set on edge and connected by a wire of high resistance.
At the receiving end each wire circuit actuates its own needle, but the two needles are at right angles and provided with light springs by which they are connected with a single vertical capillary siphon or pen with its point in contact with a paper tape. The paper at both stations is drawn along continuously by clockwork contained in the bases of the instruments.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1887–79 and 1893–256.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 43.
Object name: DELANY MULTIPLEX TELEGRAPH.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Post Office.
Date of creation: 1882–4
Object entry information: A method of simultaneously sending a number of messages in either direction along one line wire, which necessitated synchronous movements of apparatus at the two stations, was suggested by Mr. B. Meyer in 1871 and was rendered practicable for Morse working by Mr. P. B. Delany in 1882–4.
The principle is indicated by a diagram in which A and B represent two stations connected by a line wire, and x, y are two arms, rotating at equal rates over the numbered segments which are insulated from one another. If each segment be connected with transmitting and receiving instruments any message transmitted from 1 will be received at 1', from 2 at 2', and so on.
A reed and wheel arrangement patented by Mr. P. la Cour in 1878 and invented, independently, by Lord Rayleigh, is employed to drive each arm at a rate of about three revolutions per sec. The reed is kept in a state of vibration by means of an electro-magnet, the movements of the reed itself producing the necessary makes and breaks of the circuit as in a trembling bell. Included in the circuit there is a second electro-magnet, which drives a phonic-wheel and is mounted on the axis of the rotating arm. The latter consequently moves at a rate determined by the vibrations of its reed. A fly-wheel mounted on the same axis, is made of wood containing mercury in two concentric grooves.
This arrangement does not, however, ensure absolute synchronism, and further provision is made by sending and receiving correction currents. When the arm at one station is over a sending-correction group, that at the other station is over a receiving-correction group.
The number of messages which can be sent simultaneously depends on the retardation of the line.
This system was, at one time, used in this country to a limited extent, hexode working being employed between London and Birmingham.
The apparatus exhibited consists of a distributor and a reed. To render the wheel visible, the distributor has been removed from the metal ring upon which it was mounted.
(See Preece and Sivewright’s “Telegraphy,” new edition, 1905, pp. 218–232.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1911–67.
title: 24 segment Baudot plate distributor, 1870-1924

Object entry information:
The experimental transmitter and receiver are shown, together with specimens of the writing and a diagram of the general arrangement. The instruments were invented by Mr. E. A. Cowper in 1878, and have worked successfully through a resistance of 1,000 ohms.
Two line wires are used, one of which transmits a current proportional to the vertical and the other to the horizontal displacement of the transmitter’s pen from its central position. This is accomplished by having attached to this pen two jointed rods which transmit the two components of the motion to contact pieces that slide over resistance frames arranged at right angles. These frames are built up of insulated plates set on edge and connected by a wire of high resistance.
At the receiving end each wire circuit actuates its own needle, but the two needles are at right angles and provided with light springs by which they are connected with a single vertical capillary siphon or pen with its point in contact with a paper tape. The paper at both stations is drawn along continuously by clockwork contained in the bases of the instruments.

Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is a modern sending plate, of French pattern, designed for use on a Baudot quadruple telegraph set.
Revolving brushes of flexible metal sweep over the surfaces of the rings in pairs. For instance, the second ring, consisting of 24 segments, may be joined through a pair of brushes to the continuous ring number 5, which is connected to line. In this way each keyboard is in contact with the line for a fraction of a second at frequent intervals. A separate distributor plate, of slightly different construction, is required for receiving. All the brushes are, however, carried on a common spindle which passes through the central aperture of both plates.

Two line wires are used, one of which transmits a current proportional to the vertical and the other to the horizontal displacement of the transmitter’s pen from its central position. This is accomplished by having attached to this pen two jointed rods which transmit the two components of the motion to contact pieces that slide over resistance frames arranged at right angles. These frames are built up of insulated plates set on edge and connected by a wire of high resistance.
At the receiving end each wire circuit actuates its own needle, but the two needles are at right angles and provided with light springs by which they are connected with a single vertical capillary siphon or pen with its point in contact with a paper tape. Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 43.
Object name: DELANY MULTIPLEX TELEGRAPH.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Post Office.
Date of creation: 1882–4
Object entry information: A method of simultaneously sending a number of messages in either direction along one line wire, which necessitated synchronous movements of apparatus at the two stations, was suggested by Mr. B. Meyer in 1871 and was rendered practicable for Morse working by Mr. P. B. Delany in 1882–4.
The principle is indicated by a diagram in which A and B represent two stations connected by a line wire, and x, y are two arms, rotating at equal rates over the numbered segments which are insulated from one another. If each segment be connected with transmitting and receiving instruments any message transmitted from 1 will be received at 1', from 2 at 2', and so on.
A reed and wheel arrangement patented by Mr. P. la Cour in 1878 and invented, independently, by Lord Rayleigh, is employed to drive each arm at a rate of about three revolutions per sec. The reed is kept in a state of vibration by means of an electro-magnet, the movements of the reed itself producing the necessary makes and breaks of the circuit as in a trembling bell. Included in the circuit there is a second electro-magnet, which drives a phonic-wheel and is mounted on the axis of the rotating arm. The latter consequently moves at a rate determined by the vibrations of its reed. A fly-wheel mounted on the same axis, is made of wood containing mercury in two concentric grooves.
This arrangement does not, however, ensure absolute synchronism, and further provision is made by sending and receiving correction currents. When the arm at one station is over a sending-correction group, that at the other station is over a receiving-correction group.
The number of messages which can be sent simultaneously depends on the retardation of the line.
This system was, at one time, used in this country to a limited extent, hexode working being employed between London and Birmingham.
The apparatus exhibited consists of a distributor and a reed. To render the wheel visible, the distributor has been removed from the metal ring upon which it was mounted.
(See Preece and Sivewright’s “Telegraphy,” new edition, 1905, pp. 218–232.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1911–67.

Maker/Donor: Made by The Typewriting Telegraph Corporation, Ltd.
Object entry information: This step-by-step instrument was patented by Mr. W. S. Steljes in 1895–8, and has been extensively used on private lines. The communicator at the sending station is of the ordinary A B C type and has a shuttle-wound armature which transmits alternating currents. At the receiving station, these pass through the coils of an electro-magnet with a polarised armature, operating the escapement of a weight-driven train on wheels. This is connected with a type-wheel and the letter is then made to take up a position corresponding with the key depressed at the sending station. The currents also pass through a second electro-magnet, which is non-polarised and sufficiently sluggish in action to continue attracting its armature during the passage of the current. When the latter ceases, however, the armature is released and frees a second train of wheels driving an eccentric wheel, by means of a lever, raises a paper strip against the type-wheel and prints the letter signalled. The lever also operates a device for feeding forward the paper. The type-wheel is double, and consists of series of letters and figures side by side, the change from one set to the other being affected when the communicator key adjacent to “ letters ” or “ figures ” is depressed. In the example shown the arrangement for inking the type is missing. (See Herbert’s “ Telegraphy,” p. 412, 1920 edition.)

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 45.
Object name: KAMM'S ZEROGRAPH.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: 1895–1905
Object entry information: In this telegraphic typewriter, which was patented by Mr. L. Kamm in 1895–1905, the printing is done in page form at both ends of the line by similar instruments, the operator at the transmitting end simply using a keyboard as in an ordinary typewriter. Two currents are sent over the line for each signal transmitted, the interval of time between the two depending upon the letter signalled. Mounted on a vertical axis, which carries a sector bearing the type, there is an arm, termed a “ synchronising arm,” which is normally retained in its zero position by a catch. When a key is depressed, this arm is released and a spring pin connected with the key lever is raised. At the same time, a current is sent over the line, which causes the arm at the receiving end also to be released. The arms receive motion from adjustable springs, and the arm at the transmitting station moves until arrested by the raised pin, contact with which sends a second current to line and brings the distant arm also to be brought to rest. This is effected by means of a piece on the underside of the arm, which, under the action of an electro-magnet, is made to project, and, as the arm moves at equal rates, to catch against the pin corresponding with the one raised at the sending station. A local circuit at each end is closed, which energises an electro-magnet and causes the type letter corresponding to the position of the arm to be printed on the paper. The arms are then returned to their initial positions by the action of other electro-magnets. For rotating the paper roller and returning the carriage to its initial position when commencing a new line, a separate electro-magnet is provided, the exciting circuit for which is closed when the arm moves over all the pins to its extreme position, a special key with no connected pin being provided for this purpose.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1911–66.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 46.
Object name: CREED PNEUMATIC KEYBOARD PERFORATOR.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Creed & Co., Croydon.
Date of creation: About 1896
Object entry information: This apparatus was invented by F. G. Creed, Esq., about 1896, and is designed to produce perforations on Wheatstone slips at a high rate of speed with a minimum of labour. The telegraph operator, instead of having to build up Morse signals, by striking separate plungers for dots, dashes and spaces, as with the ordinary hand perforator, simply depresses a selected key, which punches the corresponding symbol complete. The instrument was used by the Post Office for about five years, and was then superseded by electrically worked keyboards which did not require a pneumatic supply.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–424.

Object entry information: In this telegraphic typewriter, which was patented by Mr. L. Kamm in 1895–1905, the printing is done in page form at both ends of the line by similar instruments, the operator at the transmitting end simply using a keyboard as in an ordinary typewriter. Two currents are sent over the line for each signal transmitted, the interval of time between the two depending upon the letter signalled. Mounted on a vertical axis, which carries a sector bearing the type, there is an arm, termed a “ synchronising arm,” which is normally retained in its zero position by a catch. When a key is depressed, this arm is released and a spring pin connected with the key lever is raised. At the same time, a current is sent over the line, which causes the arm at the receiving end also to be released. The arms receive motion from adjustable springs, and the arm at the transmitting station moves until arrested by the raised pin, contact with which sends a second current to line and brings the distant arm also to be brought to rest. This is effected by means of a piece on the underside of the arm, which, under the action of an electro-magnet, is made to project, and, as the arm moves at equal rates, to catch against the pin corresponding with the one raised at the sending station. A local circuit at each end is closed, which energises an electro-magnet and causes the type letter corresponding to the position of the arm to be printed on the paper. The arms are then returned to their initial positions by the action of other electro-magnets. For rotating the paper roller and returning the carriage to its initial position when commencing a new line, a separate electro-magnet is provided, the exciting circuit for which is closed when the arm moves over all the pins to its extreme position, a special key with no connected pin being provided for this purpose.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1911–66.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 46.
Object name: CREED PNEUMATIC KEYBOARD PERFORATOR.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Creed & Co., Croydon.
Date of creation: About 1896
Object entry information: This apparatus was invented by F. G. Creed, Esq., about 1896, and is designed to produce perforations on Wheatstone slips at a high rate of speed with a minimum of labour. The telegraph operator, instead of having to build up Morse signals, by striking separate plungers for dots, dashes and spaces, as with the ordinary hand perforator, simply depresses a selected key, which punches the corresponding symbol complete. The instrument was used by the Post Office for about five years, and was then superseded by electrically worked keyboards which did not require a pneumatic supply.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–424.
title: Creed keyboard telegraph perforator
description: Creed keyboard telegraph perforator, original design, pneumatically worked

Object name: PRELIMINARY AND FIRST COMPLETE MODELS OF THE MURRAY AUTOMATIC PRINTING TELEGRAPH.
Maker/Donor: Made and Presented by Donald Murray, Esq.
Object entry information: In machine telegraphy an operator transmits messages by playing on a keyboard, and the whole of the rest of the work is done by machinery, the chief mechanism being the telegraph printer at the receiving station. The central principle in all such machines is that of the key and lock. There is a separate key and a separate lock for each letter. The keys are assembled in the transmitting keyboard, and the locks, which are at the receiving station, form a “selector” which operates the typewriter. In modern telegraph printers the permutation lever lock is used combined with what is known as the five-unit alphabet. As about 32 of these permutation lever locks are required for letters and operation signals, they are arranged in a circle or in a straight line. The circular form was the first to come into practical use in the type-writing telegraphs, culminating in the Baudot Multiplex in 1875. The straight-line plan was old, but was first put into practical form by Mr. Donald Murray in Sydney, Australia, in 1898, in the models which are here exhibited. The preliminary wooden model, which was made in 1896, shows the essential features of all subsequent machines of the straight-line class, including the Murray automatic printer adjacent to it. This printer was taken to New York in 1901, and was developed with the assistance of the Postal Telegraph Co. into the Murray automatic printing telegraph system. This was brought to London in 1901, and after further improvement was used by the British, German, Russian and other administrations. The Murray automatic system was combined with the Baudot multiplex by Murray, with the assistance of the British Post Office, between the years 1907 and 1912, the result being the Murray multiplex (a combined Automatic-Multiplex system). From this has developed the Western Union Multiplex, the Western Electric Multiplex and the Morkrum multiplex. All these American printing telegraphs, several thousands of which are now in use, embody the same permutation lever lock principle shown in the wooden model accompanying this description.
