Catalogue number: 48.
Object name: FORBES TYPE-BAR TRANSLATOR.
Maker/Donor: Made and Presented by A. Forbes, Esq.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This remarkable type-printing telegraph is of the sliding type-bar class, but each bar has the whole alphabet on its printing face. The apparatus was constructed by the inventor, a schoolmaster by profession, purely as an experimental model, and has never been developed. Nevertheless, it worked perfectly at over 200 words per minute with type fixed by means of seccotine to type-bars made from umbrella ribs. The type-bars are supported between two toothed discs gearing with pinions on a motor shaft, which slowly revolves. Between the discs is a drum, which is stationary, and has a series of sloping grooves terminated by cam surfaces. Each type-bar has five setting pins friction-tight in the bar and arranged to be set by five magnets. The positioning of a type-bar depends upon the setting of its pins, which are spaced apart at distances, 1, 2, 4, 8 and 16 units, each unit being equal to the width of a single type. The bars are adjusted to the printing position by means of the setting pins engaging as the bar rotates with sliding grooves. In this way the required letter is at the printing point after the bar has travelled 180° from the setting point. The setting of the bar is therefore a very leisurely process, and in this respect alone the printer is unique. Each pin, after passing through a groove, is reset by a sloping cam surface on the stationary drum, while each type-bar has a small lug on its underside, which comes in contact with a sloping reset plate after passing the printing point. The working model is provided with a transmitting mechanism, which actuates the setting magnets by means of perforated tape. This tape had at first two rows of holes for advancing the paper, but one row was subsequently found more satisfactory. It was shown adjacent to the five-unit perforator shown adjacent to the instrument. (See H. Harrison, "Printing Telegraph Systems and Mechanisms.")
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–671.

Object entry information: This receiving perforator, invented and patented by Mr. F. G. Creed about 1901, is used in conjunction with the Wheatstone automatic telegraph, and produces at the receiving station a perforated tape, which is a replica of the original prepared for transmission by means of the five-unit perforator shown adjacent to the instrument. (See H. Harrison, "Printing Telegraph Systems and Mechanisms.")

title: Model high speed printing telegraph and perforating apparatus
description: Model high speed printing telegraph and perforating apparatus

Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Creed & Co., Croydon.
Object entry information: This receiving perforator, invented and patented by Mr. F. G. Creed about 1901, is used in conjunction with the Wheatstone automatic telegraph, and produces at the receiving station a perforated tape, which is a replica of the original prepared for transmission by means of the five-unit perforator shown adjacent to the instrument. (See H. Harrison, "Printing Telegraph Systems and Mechanisms.") slip passing through the Wheatstone transmitter at the sending station. The received slip may either be used for retransmission, or be passed through a Creed printer, which types the message in ordinary characters. At an intermediate transmitting office, it was formerly necessary to transcribe messages from the Morse tape and to re-perforate the signals by hand, if required for transmission over another Wheatstone circuit. By the Creed system, the perforated tape is automatically prepared by the received signals at high speed. A relay, fixed to the baseboard, carries a light arm, which moves from side to side according to the direction of the incoming current. At the end of the arm is an arrangement for opening and closing a small valve which controls the supply of compressed air—at about 30 lb. per sq. in.—to pistons. The direction of movement of the pistons determines whether a marking or a spacing hole shall be performed through the paper slip. In order to avoid tearing the paper, a mechanical contrivance arrests the movement of the paper feed wheel for about 1/300th of a second while the punch is perforating and being withdrawn from the tape. A later pattern of Creed receiving perforator, which works without air pressure, was introduced in 1921. (See also the Bille Receiving Perforator, exhibited adjacently.)

Object/Inventory number: N/A
title: Creed telegraph receiving perforator
description: Creed telegraph receiving perforator, original type, pneumatically worked

Object entry information: The messages for transmission are first punched in tape by means of this perforator, which translates the Roman letter-space signals of the written message into the five letters of the five-unit telegraph alphabet. The perforator includes a typewriter keyboard and a punch-block with five punches and an electro-magnetic, the armature of which feeds the tape forward one letter space on its back stroke. On the right may be seen the lever for pulling the tape back letter by letter when a correction is necessary. The correction is made by striking the letter-shift key (caps), which punches five holes in a letter space, and so blots out all other permutations which have been previously punched. At the other end of the line this signal leaves the printer unaffected, its function being to shift the action of the printer from figures to letters. The signal may be repeated half a dozen times so as to blot out a whole word, and there will be no trace of the error in the printed message.

Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: N/A

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 51. (2)
Object name: SINGLE-LINE TRANSMITTER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Institution of Electrical Engineers.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The perforated tape, containing a batch of three or four messages, having been prepared, the next step is automatic transmission, that is to say, collection of the space signals and transmission as time signals. There are two well-known methods of accomplishing this. The first is the direct method, in which metallic brushes make electrical contact through the holes of the paper tape. In the second, or indirect, method, the signals are transmitted by the intervention of a number of small levers and rods controlled by the tape. This method, which is similar in principle to the Jacquard loom, was first used in the Wheatstone automatic transmitter, and experience has shown it to be the best. It is used in the present case.
The name of the instrument is derived from the fact that the slip perforations are in a single row. The transmitter automatically sends out a train of five currents impulse of a time, corresponding to one letter or character, with distinct pauses between each train.
With regard to any one train, if there is no current perforation in the corresponding five centre hole length of slip, the five current impulses are all negative, actually forming one continuous negative current. If, however, one or more perforations occur, the corresponding current impulses to line are positive in direction and the remainder of the five are negative.
A diagram placed beside the instrument shows the alphabet employed and (Figs. 2 and 3) the resulting currents to line produced by the passage of slip perforated with the word "and."
For a detailed description of the mechanism of the transmitter, see Crotch’s “Telegraphic Systems,” 1908, or the inventor’s description in the I.E.E. Journal for February, 1905.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923-230.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 52. (3)
Object name: RECEIVING PERFORATOR.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: At the receiving station, the signals operate a polarised relay, in the local circuit of which is connected an electro-magnetic perforator. This consists essentially of a punching and a spacing magnet operated through contacts closed alternately by a vibrating reed. The speed of the latter is governed by a relay, so that it is kept in unison with the reed of a phonic-wheel which is incorporated in the transmitter. The receiving perforator produces a facsimile of the transmitting tape, which is then available for retransmission or for printing.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-149, 152.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 53. (4)
Object name: RECEIVING PRINTER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: If the tape is not required for retransmission, the tape signals have to be translated into Roman signals and printed. The essential features of the Murray printer have been described in the label which accompanied the original models.
The tape is fed along letter by letter (five units at a time) by a star-wheel carried on a shuttle, which is kept reciprocating by means of a cam. Each reciprocation rotates the star-wheel one letter space. The shuttle carries a die-plate coinciding with the circumference of the star-wheel and having five holes corresponding with the message holes in the tape.

With regard to any one train, if there is no current perforation in the corresponding five centre hole length of slip, the five current impulses are all negative, actually forming one continuous negative current. If, however, one or more perforations occur, the corresponding current impulses to line are positive in direction and the remainder of the five are negative.
A diagram placed beside the instrument shows the alphabet employed and (Figs. 2 and 3) the resulting currents to line produced by the passage of slip perforated with the word "and."
For a detailed description of the mechanism of the transmitter, see Crotch’s “Telegraphic Systems,” 1908, or the inventor’s description in the I.E.E. Journal for February, 1905.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923-230.

Object entry information: The messages for transmission are first punched in tape by means of this perforator, which translates the Roman letter-space signals of the written message into the five letters of the five-unit telegraph alphabet. The perforator includes a typewriter keyboard and a punch-block with five punches and an electro-magnetic, the armature of which feeds the tape forward one letter space on its back stroke. On the right may be seen the lever for pulling the tape back letter by letter when a correction is necessary. The correction is made by striking the letter-shift key (caps), which punches five holes in a letter space, and so blots out all other permutations which have been previously punched. At the other end of the line this signal leaves the printer unaffected, its function being to shift the action of the printer from figures to letters. The signal may be repeated half a dozen times so as to blot out a whole word, and there will be no trace of the error in the printed message.

Object entry information: The perforated tape, containing a batch of three or four messages, having been prepared, the next step is automatic transmission, that is to say, collection of the space signals and transmission as time signals. There are two well-known methods of accomplishing this. The first is the direct method, in which metallic brushes make electrical contact through the holes of the paper tape. In the second, or indirect, method, the signals are transmitted by the intervention of a number of small levers and rods controlled by the tape. This method, which is similar in principle to the Jacquard loom, was first used in the Wheatstone automatic transmitter, and experience has shown it to be the best. It is used in the present case.

title: Relay, local Murray auto 2/2
description: Relay, local Murray auto 2/2

Object entry information:
If the tape is not required for retransmission, the tape signals have to be translated into Roman signals and printed. The essential features of the Murray printer have been described in the label which accompanied the original models.
The tape is fed along letter by letter (five units at a time) by a star-wheel carried on a shuttle, which is kept reciprocating by means of a cam. Each reciprocation rotates the star-wheel one letter space. The shuttle carries a die-plate coinciding with the circumference of the star-wheel and having five holes corresponding with the message holes in the tape. Five rods, fixed in the ends of five slotted combs, are free to enter the five holes in the die-plate if they are not obstructed by the paper tape which passes between the rods and the plate. On its inward stroke the shuttle with its die-plate presses the tape against the ends of the rods and those that are opposite holes in the tape pass through into the die-plate. By this means one particular group of slots in the combs, and only one out of 56, is brought into alignment so that a cross-bar can drop into it and cause a letter to print. From the point of view of the theory of machines, the combs form a complicated series of 56 permutation locks. The 56 cross-bars are the bolts or latches, and the universal bar which is really a universal key. The locks are continually being closed in different ways by the tape, and the universal key is continually opening the locks. This intricate system of keys and locks is inevitable in all cases where complex control is needed. Amongst other instances it is used in systems of railroad interlocking gear, and although there is no outward resemblance between the Murray and the Baudot telegraph systems, the principle of the permutation locks is the same in both cases, and indeed in all high-speed printing telegraph systems.

title: Murray auto printer, incomplete
description: Murray auto printer, incomplete

Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Creed & Co., Croydon.
Object entry information: This instrument, like the Creed receiving perforator, is designed to reproduce perforated Wheatstone slips from the action set up by the incoming line currents. The apparatus is operated electrically and does not require a supply of compressed air. On the spindle of an electric motor, a disc, carrying cams on its front surface, is rotated. These cams in revolving pass over small rollers attached to the back portions of the marking and spacing punches. Between the back and front of each punch is a small gap, which is filled up by a bell-crank lever when the punch is required to perforate a hole in the paper. The position of each bell-crank lever is governed by the action of one of the two side electro-magnets, one being energised by positive and the other by negative condenser impulses. In each case, the attraction of the armature of the electro-magnet turns the corresponding bell-crank lever—to which it is attached by a thin brass strip—into a position to fill the gap. The appropriate cam on the revolving disc then forces the punch through the paper. At the end of the stroke, the heel of the bell-crank lever is brought into contact with a small pin, which turns it aside so that the punch does not again perforate the paper until the electro-magnet has been re-energised.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 55.
Object name: HARRISON START-STOP PRINTER.
Maker/Donor: Manufactured and Lent by The Automatic Telephone Manufacturing Co., Ltd. Plate 5.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This instrument was invented by Mr. H. H. Harrison, and is a good example of modern development in printing telegraph construction. The selecting mechanism is of the permutation disc pattern, and the type-wheel shaft is continuously rotated as in Hughes and Baudot printers. An original and effective method of shifting the type-wheel from the letter to the figure group is one of the principal features of the apparatus. The distributor is of the start-stop type, in which both the transmitting and receiving brush arms are automatically started and stopped by the current. The adjacent keyboard transmitter forms the sending portion of the equipment. (See “Telegraph Printing Systems and Mechanisms,” by H. H. Harrison.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1925–86.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 56.
Object name: HARRISON KEYBOARD TRANSMITTER.
Maker/Donor: Manufactured and Lent by The Automatic Telephone Manufacturing Co., Ltd. Plate 5.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This modern apparatus is the sending portion of the Harrison type-printing system. The depression of a key selects the combination of positive and negative currents required to signal the desired symbol, and also causes an unlocking current to pass through the start magnets at both stations. This releases the brush arms, which are then carried round by the motor shafts to which they are frictionally coupled. The brushes sweep over corresponding segments of the distributor at both ends of the line, and the order of the marking and spacing currents determines the character to be printed at the receiving station.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1925–89.

Maker/Donor: Lent by The Automatic Telephone Manufacturing Co., Ltd.
Object entry information: This apparatus was recently invented by S. R. Smith, Esq., and is designed to store up a number of signals in readiness for transmission over a circuit where the sending instrument operates at definite time intervals. In such cases, the telegraphist, working with a storage transmitter, has to observe the pauses, but if he works the key-board direct to line, has to observe any desired speed, the symbols being stored and transmitted in turn. The depression of a key lever causes metal pins to project from one of a series of radial lines of holes in a disc, the projections being in accordance with the symbol selected. The disc is constantly revolving, and each line of pins is in turn brought into connection with contact springs controlling a relay which sends the selected currents to line. After performing this function, the pins are restored to normal in readiness for further selection.

Smith, Esq., and is designed to store up a number of signals in readiness for transmission over a circuit where the sending instrument operates at definite time intervals. Object entry information: These are specimens of the early submarine cables which were laid across the Atlantic Ocean. The first was successfully completed in August, 1858, but broke down after a few weeks' existence. It was ascertained later that the high power used to transmit the signals had permanently injured the gutta-percha insulation of the conductor. The instrument on which the first words from Newfoundland were received at Valentia is shown in another part of this case (see Henley’s galvanometer, Cat. No. 59). The next attempt to lay an Atlantic cable was made in 1865, when the “Great Eastern,” at that time the largest commercial ship afloat, was specially fitted with cable tanks for the enterprise. In spite of every care, however, breakages during the process of laying the cable were so numerous that the project had to be abandoned. A new cable was manufactured in 1866, and this was successfully laid. The cable of the previous year was then grappled, after 30 attempts, and the end was brought to the surface from a depth of over two miles. New cable was provided to complete the work, which was carried to a satisfactory termination. Thus two cables became available for communication between this country and America. The specimens shown are:— ATLANTIC CABLE, 1858. No. 1.—Main cable. No. 2.—Shore end. Length, 2,174 nautical miles. ATLANTIC CABLE, 1865. No. 1.—Main cable. No. 2.—Shore end. Length, 2,300 nautical miles. ATLANTIC CABLE, 1866. No. 1.—Main cable. No. 2.—Shore end. Length, 1,852 nautical miles. ATLANTIC CABLE, 1865. Recovered from a depth of 1,950 fathoms after 13 months’ submersion. MODEL GRAPNEL. Model of grapnel used in recovery of 1865 cable. GRAPNEL ROPE. Used in recovery of 1865 cable.

Maker/Donor: Made by Messrs. Jas. White & Co. / Lent by The Institution of Electrical Engineers.
Object entry information: The siphon recorder was patented by Lord Kelvin (then Sir William Thomson) in 1867. The instrument shown was one of the original six sent out in 1870 by the Eastern Telegraph Co. It was worked in Egypt, on the main line to India, until 1882, and later on less important lines. A few of the parts are missing. The essential portions of the apparatus are powerful magnets terminated in soft iron pole pieces with a narrow gap between them. Within the gap, and consequently lying in a strong magnetic field, a thin rectangular coil of very fine silk covered copper wire is lightly suspended. The feeble current received from a long submarine cable passes through the coil and causes it to turn to the right or left according to the direction of the current. These movements are conveyed to a delicate glass siphon, one end of which dips into an inkwell, while the other end lies over a paper tape on which a wavy line, corresponding to the deflections, is traced. The instrument was first made in it simplest form, except that a method of reducing the friction of the glass on the paper, by causing the siphon to be vibrated by a trembler bell arrangement, has rendered the instrument still more sensitive to weak currents and enables long cables to be worked at a somewhat higher speed.

Object entry information:
The original form of curb sender for diminishing the effect of inductive retardation in long-submarine cables was designed by Lord Kelvin in 1858. The instrument here shown, which is due to Messrs. Taylor, Dearlove and Brown, is a special form of curb sender for correctly retransmitting the signals received on a relay, and was patented by Mr. S. G. Brown, F.R.S., in 1899. The relay mentioned was designed to overcome the difficulty of securing sufficiently good electrical contact under the slight pressure obtainable from an instrument actuated by weak arrival currents at the end of a long cable. The point of a contact arm (representing the siphon in the ordinary form of recorder) was caused to traverse the cylindrical surface of a rapidly rotating drum. This surface was divided into two parallel halves by a short insulating space on which the arm normally rested, so that two separate conducting surfaces were provided, with either of which the arm would make contact in its excursions from the central position.
The special form of curb sender here shown is designed to secure the correct retransmission of any given number of consecutive elements of a letter which are of the same sign, but which signals are received at the end of a long cable; the relay arm will not return to its zero position between consecutive elements of the same sign, but will remain on the respective contact surface during the whole time occupied by such consecutive elements.
The instrument consists of two cams, the form of which regulates the component of the curb-fed signal, one cam being for the dot element and the other for the dash. These cams, by means of clutches controlled by the relay, are mechanically rotated by clockwork, the speed of rotation being approximately adjusted to the rate of transmission of a single element; so that the requisite number of consecutive elements is transmitted, corresponding to the duration of contact of the relay arm with the side controlling that particular element.
By a modification of the apparatus the message, instead of being immediately retransmitted, can be punched on a slip which can be inserted in an automatic transmitter.
(See “Encyclopædia Britannica,” 11th edition.)

Object entry information: conductor. The instrument on which the first words from Newfoundland were received at Valentia is shown in another part of this case (see Henley’s galvanometer, Cat. No. 59). The next attempt to lay an Atlantic cable was made in 1865, when the “Great Eastern,” at that time the largest commercial ship afloat, was specially fitted with cable tanks for the enterprise. In spite of every care, however, breakages during the process of laying the cable were so numerous that the project had to be abandoned. A new cable was manufactured in 1866, and this was successfully laid. The cable of the previous year was then grappled, after 30 attempts, and the end was brought to the surface from a depth of over two miles. New cable was provided to complete the work, which was carried to a satisfactory termination. Thus two cables became available for communication between this country and America. The specimens shown are:— ATLANTIC CABLE, 1858. No. 1.—Main cable. No. 2.—Shore end. Length, 2,174 nautical miles. ATLANTIC CABLE, 1865. No. 1.—Main cable. No. 2.—Shore end. Length, 2,300 nautical miles. ATLANTIC CABLE, 1866. No. 1.—Main cable. No. 2.—Shore end. Length, 1,852 nautical miles. ATLANTIC CABLE, 1865. Recovered from a depth of 1,950 fathoms after 13 months’ submersion. MODEL GRAPNEL. Model of grapnel used in recovery of 1865 cable. GRAPNEL ROPE. Used in recovery of 1865 cable.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 62.
Object name: SIPHON RECORDER.
Maker/Donor: Made by Messrs. Jas. White & Co. / Lent by The Institution of Electrical Engineers.
Date of creation: 1867
Object entry information: The siphon recorder was patented by Lord Kelvin (then Sir William Thomson) in 1867. The instrument shown was one of the original six sent out in 1870 by the Eastern Telegraph Co. It was worked in Egypt, on the main line to India, until 1882, and later on less important lines. A few of the parts are missing. The essential portions of the apparatus are powerful magnets terminated in soft iron pole pieces with a narrow gap between them. Within the gap, and consequently lying in a strong magnetic field, a thin rectangular coil of very fine silk covered copper wire is lightly suspended. The feeble current received from a long submarine cable passes through the coil and causes it to turn to the right or left according to the direction of the current. These movements are conveyed to a delicate glass siphon, one end of which dips into an inkwell, while the other end lies over a paper tape on which a wavy line, corresponding to the deflections, is traced. The instrument was first made in it simplest form, except that a method of reducing the friction of the glass on the paper, by causing the siphon to be vibrated by a trembler bell arrangement, has rendered the instrument still more sensitive to weak currents and enables long cables to be worked at a somewhat higher speed.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919–350.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 63.
Object name: INTERPOLATOR.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Elliott Bros.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The original form of curb sender for diminishing the effect of inductive retardation in long-submarine cables was designed by Lord Kelvin in 1858. The instrument here shown, which is due to Messrs. Taylor, Dearlove and Brown, is a special form of curb sender for correctly retransmitting the signals received on a relay, and was patented by Mr. S. G. Brown, F.R.S., in 1899.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–233.
title: Brown's interpolator, 1899
description: Brown's interpolator, 1899

Maker/Donor: Presented by The Eastern Associated Telegraph Companies.
Object entry information: This relay, designed by S. G. Brown, Esq., F.R.S., receives signals attenuated after transmission through a long submarine cable, and restores them to their original strength before retransmission through a second cable. The signal currents pass through a coil delicately suspended in a strong magnetic field. The automatic transmitter (i.e. a battery reverser operated by perforated tape) at the distant end of the cable causes the received currents to traverse the coil in one direction for a Morse dot and in the opposite direction for a Morse dot. Thus the coil makes a small angular movement either to right or left, and a contact-making pointer to which it is harnessed is deflected on to one or other of two silver discs and thereby closes the local circuit of the dot or dash retransmitting relay. A feature of this instrument is the method of eliminating friction between the pointer and the adjacent silver contacts by rotating the latter at a moderate speed through the medium of a small electric motor. Without this device the minute forces of the signal currents would not suffice to move the pointer. (See also Cat. No. 68, Dipper Relay.)
Raw_Response:
Continuation from previous page: TRUE
Catalogue number: N/A
Object name: N/A
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The relay mentioned was designed to overcome the difficulty of securing sufficiently good electrical contact under the slight pressure obtainable from an instrument actuated by weak arrival currents at the end of a long cable. The point of a contact arm (representing the siphon in the ordinary form of recorder) was caused to traverse the cylindrical surface of a rapidly rotating drum. This surface was divided into two parallel halves by a short insulating space on which the arm normally rested, so that two separate conducting surfaces were provided, with either of which the arm would make contact in its excursions from the central position.
The special form of curb sender here shown is designed to secure the correct retransmission of any given number of consecutive elements of a letter which are of the same sign, but which signals are received at the end of a long cable; the relay arm will not return to its zero position between consecutive elements of the same sign, but will remain on the respective contact surface during the whole time occupied by such consecutive elements.
The instrument consists of two cams, the form of which regulates the component of the curb-fed signal, one cam being for the dot element and the other for the dash. These cams, by means of clutches controlled by the relay, are mechanically rotated by clockwork, the speed of rotation being approximately adjusted to the rate of transmission of a single element; so that the requisite number of consecutive elements is transmitted, corresponding to the duration of contact of the relay arm with the side controlling that particular element.
By a modification of the apparatus the message, instead of being immediately retransmitted, can be punched on a slip which can be inserted in an automatic transmitter.
(See “Encyclopædia Britannica,” 11th edition.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–416.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 66.
Object name: KEYBOARD PERFORATOR.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Eastern Associated Telegraph Companies.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The object of this instrument is to enable the cable companies to prepare the perforated tape used in the automatic transmission of telegrams. It produces the telegraph tape at a far higher speed than either the signal key perforator or the ordinary “two-hand” perforator by reason of the fact that the perforation of a letter is completed by a single depression of the appropriate lever, whereas in other instruments each body physical movement on the part of the operator, e.g. a letter H in the Morse code, involving four distinct impulses on the ordinary perforator, is completed in a single impulse on the keyboard perforator.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1925–187.

Maker/Donor: Presented by The Eastern Associated Telegraph Companies.
Object entry information: This instrument was designed in 1902 to prepare the perforated tape used in the automatic transmission of telegrams. The feature of this instrument is that the perforating mechanism is controlled by the same type of hand key as is used for direct hand transmission and with which, therefore, all cable operators are familiar. As the manipulation of the hand key calls for less exertion than is the case with the ordinary two-hand operated perforator, the instrument is specially suitable for use at tropical stations.

Catalogue number: 67.
Object name: SIGNAL KEY PERFORATOR.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Eastern Associated Telegraph Companies.
Date of creation: 1902
Object entry information: This instrument was designed in 1902 to prepare the perforated tape used in the automatic transmission of telegrams. The feature of this instrument is that the perforating mechanism is controlled by the same type of hand key as is used for direct hand transmission and with which, therefore, all cable operators are familiar. As the manipulation of the hand key calls for less exertion than is the case with the ordinary two-hand operated perforator, the instrument is specially suitable for use at tropical stations.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1925–289.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 68.
Object name: DIPPER RELAY.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Eastern Associated Telegraph Companies.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is an instrument designed to receive signals attenuated after transmission through a long submarine cable and to restore them to their original strength before retransmission through a second cable. The signal currents pass through a coil delicately suspended in a magnetic field. The coil makes a small angular movement in one direction for a dash and in the opposite direction for a Morse dot. At the same time, one or other of two fine platinum wire electrodes to which the coil is harnessed dip into an acid bath and thus complete a local circuit through the “dot” or “dash” retransmitting relays.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1925–188.

Catalogue number: 67.
Object name: SIGNAL KEY PERFORATOR.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Eastern Associated Telegraph Companies.
Date of creation: 1902
Object entry information: This instrument was designed in 1902 to prepare the perforated tape used in the automatic transmission of telegrams. The feature of this instrument is that the perforating mechanism is controlled by the same type of hand key as is used for direct hand transmission and with which, therefore, all cable operators are familiar. As the manipulation of the hand key calls for less exertion than is the case with the ordinary two-hand operated perforator, the instrument is specially suitable for use at tropical stations.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1925–289.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 68.
Object name: DIPPER RELAY.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Eastern Associated Telegraph Companies.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is an instrument designed to receive signals attenuated after transmission through a long submarine cable and to restore them to their original strength before retransmission through a second cable. The signal currents pass through a coil delicately suspended in a magnetic field. The coil makes a small angular movement in one direction for a dash and in the opposite direction for a Morse dot. At the same time, one or other of two fine platinum wire electrodes to which the coil is harnessed dip into an acid bath and thus complete a local circuit through the “dot” or “dash” retransmitting relays.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1925–188.

Catalogue number: 81.
Object name: TRAP PLUMBER LEAD.
Maker/Donor: Presented by the Eastern Telegraph Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This has been devised for the purpose of securing a larger sample of sea bottom than is usually obtained. A tube runs through the centre of the lead with a valve at each end. On the lead striking the bottom, the impact forces the deposit into the tube and opens the valves, which close automatically directly the lead is hauled up, thus retaining the sample.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1925-173.

Object name: DETACHABLE SOUNDING SHOT AND TUBE.

Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: For use in depths over 600 fathoms. As the gear is lowered, the cap of the tube is held clear of the end. On impact the tube collects sample of bottom, the detaching hook releases shot, which capsizes, and the tube is raised clear of shot, as shown in sketch.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1925-174.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 83.
Object name: THE 1924 ATLANTIC CABLE. Telescopic Specimen.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Telegraph Construction and Maintenance Co.
Date of creation: 1924
Object entry information: This is a portion of the submarine cable laid between New York and the Azores for the Western Union Telegraph Co. It is continuously loaded with a new magnetic alloy, developed by the Western Electric Co., which strengthens the magnetic field 2,000 times. It represents the first radical change in submarine cable construction for more than 50 years. In contrast to the other electrical industries, the development of submarine cables has been slow and conservative, owing to the great expense involved in any large-scale experiments. In 1887 the late Oliver Heaviside investigated the problems raised by the large capacity of long cables, and showed how the effects could be counteracted by the insertion of loading coils. In 1899 the suggestion was taken up by Pupin, who gave practical details for this method, but it was not until 1906 that the first Pupinised underwater cable was laid, in Lake Constance. In 1902 it was proposed by Krarup for loading the cable continuously by wrapping an iron wire round the copper conductor, but the losses in ordinary iron were found to offset the gains, so that the method was never extensively used, while it was found impossible to surmount the mechanical difficulties of jointing, &c., for the use of Pupin coils in deep-sea cables. The discovery of “Permalloy,” a heat-treated nickel-iron alloy having a permeability 2,000 as great as ordinary iron, has made it possible to revert to continuous loading. The alloy is made in the form of tape, 6/100ths in. thick, and is wound immediately over the copper core. An experimental length of 120 miles of cable loaded in this manner was submerged to a depth of 2½ miles at Bermuda on the 13th October, 1923, and this having proved entirely satisfactory, the full 2,300 miles necessary for an Atlantic cable were manufactured forthwith.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

In 1887 the late Oliver Heaviside investigated the problems raised by the large capacity of long cables, and showed how the effects could be counteracted by the insertion of loading coils. In 1899 the suggestion was taken up by Pupin, who gave practical details for this method, but it was not until 1906 that the first Pupinised underwater cable was laid, in Lake Constance. In 1902 it was proposed by Krarup for loading the cable continuously by wrapping an iron wire round the copper conductor, but the losses in ordinary iron were found to offset the gains, so that the method was never extensively used, while it was found impossible to surmount the mechanical difficulties of jointing, &c., for the use of Pupin coils in deep-sea cables. The discovery of “Permalloy,” a heat-treated nickel-iron alloy having a permeability 2,000 as great as ordinary iron, has made it possible to revert to continuous loading. The alloy is made in the form of tape, 6/100ths in. thick, and is wound immediately over the copper core. The discovery of “Permalloy,” a heat-treated nickel-iron alloy having a permeability 2,000 as great as ordinary iron, has made it possible to revert to continuous loading. The alloy is made in the form of tape, 6/100ths in. thick, and is wound immediately over the copper core. An experimental length of 120 miles of cable loaded in this manner was submerged to a depth of 2½ miles at Bermuda on the 13th October, 1923, and this having proved entirely satisfactory, the full 2,300 miles necessary for an Atlantic cable were manufactured forthwith.

Maker/Donor: Presented by The Telegraph Construction and Maintenance Co.
Object entry information: This is a portion of the submarine cable laid between New York and the Azores for the Western Union Telegraph Co. It is continuously loaded with a new magnetic alloy, developed by the Western Electric Co., which strengthens the magnetic field 2,000 times. It represents the first radical change in submarine cable construction for more than 50 years. In contrast to the other electrical industries, the development of submarine cables has been slow and conservative, owing to the great expense involved in any large-scale experiments. In 1887 the late Oliver Heaviside investigated the problems raised by the large capacity of long cables, and showed how the effects could be counteracted by the insertion of loading coils. In 1899 the suggestion was taken up by Pupin, who gave practical details for this method, but it was not until 1906 that the first Pupinised underwater cable was laid, in Lake Constance. In 1902 it was proposed by Krarup for loading the cable continuously by wrapping an iron wire round the copper conductor, but the losses in ordinary iron were found to offset the gains, so that the method was never extensively used, while it was found impossible to surmount the mechanical difficulties of jointing, &c., for the use of Pupin coils in deep-sea cables. The discovery of “Permalloy,” a heat-treated nickel-iron alloy having a permeability 2,000 as great as ordinary iron, has made it possible to revert to continuous loading. The alloy is made in the form of tape, 6/100ths in. thick, and is wound immediately over the copper core. An experimental length of 120 miles of cable loaded in this manner was submerged to a depth of 2½ miles at Bermuda on the 13th October, 1923, and this having proved entirely satisfactory, the full 2,300 miles necessary for an Atlantic cable were manufactured forthwith. The counteraction of capacity effect given by the new form of loading has resulted in a manifold increase in the traffic capacity, while it is stated that there is no limit to the length of cable which could now be operated without intermediate relays. The possibilities in the Pacific Ocean are greater than in the Atlantic, as fewer facilities exist there already.

Object entry information: Several insulators of patterns used between 1837 and 1847 are shown, on a pole of the type used by Sir W. F. Cooke. (a) Iron wire, and (b) three-strand copper wire, both passing through Cooke's original goose-quill insulators, used on the line between Paddington and West Drayton, 1838–9. (c) Cooke and Wheatstone's original ring insulator, 1840. (d) Double cone insulator original form, 1845. (e) Double shed insulator (1847), in which the hook that carries the line wire is insulated by mastic cement in a cavity at the top of the insulator. (f) Split form of double cone insulator, used for replacing broken ones.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 85.
Object name: WALKER'S DOUBLE CONE INSULATOR.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: 1850
Object entry information: This brown earthenware insulator was, in practice, threaded on to the conductor, and secured to its support by a staple which passed round the central groove. This type of insulator was used by the inventor, Mr. C. V. Walker, on the telegraph lines of the South Eastern Railway, in succession to Cooke's barrel type, in 1850, and remained in service until 1878.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1915–438.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 86.
Object name: GLASS INSULATORS.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: These are two glass insulators of an early pattern. Glass was found to be unsuitable material for use in this country owing to its brittleness and the condensation of films of moisture on its surface. It is, however, used to a considerable extent in America.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1915–256.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 87.
Object name: VACUUM LIGHTNING ARRESTERS.
Maker/Donor: Lent by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: 1847
Object entry information: Arresters are designed to carry away the great rush of current that results from a lightning flash near a line, and so prevent injury to the operators or the instruments. The charge in a line from lightning is of such potential that it will leap air gaps or other resistances that are quite impassable to the battery current, and it is upon this difference that the action of most arresters relies. The vacuum arrester was invented by Mr. C. F. Varley in 1847, although not patented till 1861, and is for the protection of an underground line connected with an overhead one. From the line, wire is led to platinum terminals fixed into a glass globe, in which is also a wire connected to the earth. The line terminals end in points close to the earth wire, and by exhausting the air from the globe the resistance of the gap is so reduced as to leave a ready path for high-tension electricity. (a) This form of arrester was brought out by Mr. Varley about 1856, and is designed for protecting six line wires. It consists of six metal points, each one connected to a line wire, and fixed radially in close proximity to a ring connected to earth; the whole is covered with a glass bell-jar (missing), under which probably contained a chemical that absorbed the gas in the bell, and the other mercury, which acted as a barometer column. (b) This is a smaller and modern form of the vacuum arrester (a), and is intended for a single line.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876–1329; 1888–210–1.
title: Specimens of insulators for aerial lines
description: Five specimens of old insulators for aerial lines mounted on a wooden post

Object entry information: Arresters are designed to carry away the great rush of current that results from a lightning flash near a line, and so prevent injury to the operators or the instruments. The charge in a line from lightning is of such potential that it will leap air gaps or other resistances that are quite impassable to the battery current, and it is upon this difference that the action of most arresters relies. The vacuum arrester was invented by Mr. C. F. Varley in 1847, although not patented till 1861, and is for the protection of an underground line connected with an overhead one. From the line, wire is led to platinum terminals fixed into a glass globe, in which is also a wire connected to the earth. The line terminals end in points close to the earth wire, and by exhausting the air from the globe the resistance of the gap is so reduced as to leave a ready path for high-tension electricity. (a) This form of arrester was brought out by Mr. Varley about 1856, and is designed for protecting six line wires. It consists of six metal points, each one connected to a line wire, and fixed radially in close proximity to a ring connected to earth; the whole is covered with a glass bell-jar (missing), under which probably contained a chemical that absorbed the gas in the bell, and the other mercury, which acted as a barometer column. (b) This is a smaller and modern form of the vacuum arrester (a), and is intended for a single line.
Raw_Response:
Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 84.
Object name: INSULATORS.
Maker/Donor: Lent by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: 1838–9
Object entry information: Several insulators of patterns used between 1837 and 1847 are shown, on a pole of the type used by Sir W. F. Cooke. (a) Iron wire, and (b) three-strand copper wire, both passing through Cooke's original goose-quill insulators, used on the line between Paddington and West Drayton, 1838–9. (c) Cooke and Wheatstone's original ring insulator, 1840. (d) Double cone insulator original form, 1845. (e) Double shed insulator (1847), in which the hook that carries the line wire is insulated by mastic cement in a cavity at the top of the insulator. (f) Split form of double cone insulator, used for replacing broken ones.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1884–184.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 85.
Object name: WALKER'S DOUBLE CONE INSULATOR.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: 1850
Object entry information: This brown earthenware insulator was, in practice, threaded on to the conductor, and secured to its support by a staple which passed round the central groove. This type of insulator was used by the inventor, Mr. C. V. Walker, on the telegraph lines of the South Eastern Railway, in succession to Cooke's barrel type, in 1850, and remained in service until 1878.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1915–438.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 86.
Object name: GLASS INSULATORS.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: These are two glass insulators of an early pattern. Glass was found to be unsuitable material for use in this country owing to its brittleness and the condensation of films of moisture on its surface. It is, however, used to a considerable extent in America.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1915–256.

title: Varley's globe vacuum lightning protector, 1861
description: Varley's globe vacuum lightning protector, 1861

Maker/Donor: Lent by The Institution of Electrical Engineers.
Object entry information: This lightning protector, which was patented in 1866 by C. and S. A. Varley, is a duplicate of one shown in the "Wireless Telegraphy and Telephony Section" (See Part II of this Catalogue, Exhibit No 21). The apparatus, which is not only a lightning arrester, but exhibits also the properties of a wireless coherer, consists of two copper points, nearly touching each other, set in a small box filled with powdered carbon. In the patent specification, it is mentioned that "powdered conducting matter offers great resistance to a current of moderate tension, but offers little resistance to a current of high tension."

Catalogue number: 89.
Object name: OIL CUP INSULATOR.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: 1876
Object entry information: This white porcelain insulator was suspended from the arm of the pole. The cup is intended to contain an insulating fluid, preferably a hydrocarbon. The dished cover, which projects beyond the edge of the insulator, protects the contents from dust and rain. The cover rotates round the bolt by the action of the wind upon the metal vane (broken off). This is intended to prevent leakage of current due to cobwebs bridging the surface of the insulator. Messrs. Johnson & Phillips's Patent No. 3534, 1876.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1915–500.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 90.
Object name: VULCANITE TERMINAL INSULATOR.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is an early double-shed insulator made of vulcanite, a material which was found to be unsuitable owing to deterioration of its surface when exposed to all weathers.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1915–261.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 91.
Object name: PLATE LIGHTNING ARRESTERS.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: These are brass plate lightning arresters of types still used, in which the opposing flat surfaces are separated by sheets of mica. Holes in the latter form air gaps, across which the lightning discharge passes. Three examples are shown: one has rectangular plates and a mica sheet with two rectangular holes, while the other two have circular plates with mica discs perforated by three circular holes. One of these latter examples consists of three plates separated by two mica discs, the middle plate being connected with earth, and the upper and lower plates with the up and down lines respectively. In each case the screws which hold the plates together are insulated from the top plates by an insulating bush. One of the examples has been sectioned.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1911–34–6.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 92.
Object name: LIGHTNING ARRESTER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: 1889
Object entry information: This arrester for protecting telephone and telegraphic instruments, &c., was patented by Sir Oliver Lodge in 1889, and made by Messrs. Muirhead & Co. There are five spark gaps made by two series of rods, the rods of each series being connected together by self-induction coils. The gaps are adjustable and decrease toward the terminals to which the instruments are connected, the last gap being small and made between two fine platinum points. The self-induction of the coils does not interfere with the ordinary current through the circuit, but chokes back a discharge of any magnitude, and forces it to escape through the air gaps. The major portion of a lightning discharge passes across the first gap while the remainder is filtered through the other gaps.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914–808.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 93.
Object name: PURVES AND SINNOTT'S LEADING-IN INSULATOR.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: 1907
Object entry information: This white porcelain, double-shed, leading-in insulator was patented in 1907 by Messrs. T. F. Purves and J. Sinnott. Two grooves are provided, each having a channel communicating with a sealing chamber, from which the covered leading-in wire passes through a somewhat larger third channel, into the interior of the insulator. The sealing chamber is covered with a screw cap.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1915–543.

Object entry information: This white porcelain, double-shed, leading-in insulator was patented in 1907 by Messrs. T. F. Purves and J. Sinnott. Two grooves are provided, each having a channel communicating with a sealing chamber, from which the covered leading-in wire passes through a somewhat larger third channel, into the interior of the insulator. The sealing chamber is covered with a screw cap.

Catalogue number: 88.
Object name: VARLEY'S CARBON LIGHTNING PROTECTOR.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Institution of Electrical Engineers.
Date of creation: 1866
Object entry information: This lightning protector, which was patented in 1866 by C. and S. A. Varley, is a duplicate of one shown in the "Wireless Telegraphy and Telephony Section" (See Part II of this Catalogue, Exhibit No 21). The apparatus, which is not only a lightning arrester, but exhibits also the properties of a wireless coherer, consists of two copper points, nearly touching each other, set in a small box filled with powdered carbon. In the patent specification, it is mentioned that "powdered conducting matter offers great resistance to a current of moderate tension, but offers little resistance to a current of high tension."
Object/Inventory number: Inv 1923–269.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 89.
Object name: OIL CUP INSULATOR.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: 1876
Object entry information: This white porcelain insulator was suspended from the arm of the pole. The cup is intended to contain an insulating fluid, preferably a hydrocarbon. The dished cover, which projects beyond the edge of the insulator, protects the contents from dust and rain. The cover rotates round the bolt by the action of the wind upon the metal vane (broken off). This is intended to prevent leakage of current due to cobwebs bridging the surface of the insulator. Messrs. Johnson & Phillips's Patent No. 3534, 1876.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1915–500.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 90.
Object name: VULCANITE TERMINAL INSULATOR.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is an early double-shed insulator made of vulcanite, a material which was found to be unsuitable owing to deterioration of its surface when exposed to all weathers.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1915–261.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 91.
Object name: PLATE LIGHTNING ARRESTERS.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: These are brass plate lightning arresters of types still used, in which the opposing flat surfaces are separated by sheets of mica. Holes in the latter form air gaps, across which the lightning discharge passes. Three examples are shown: one has rectangular plates and a mica sheet with two rectangular holes, while the other two have circular plates with mica discs perforated by three circular holes. One of these latter examples consists of three plates separated by two mica discs, the middle plate being connected with earth, and the upper and lower plates with the up and down lines respectively. In each case the screws which hold the plates together are insulated from the top plates by an insulating bush. One of the examples has been sectioned.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1911–34–6.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 92.
Object name: LIGHTNING ARRESTER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: 1889
Object entry information: This arrester for protecting telephone and telegraphic instruments, &c., was patented by Sir Oliver Lodge in 1889, and made by Messrs. Muirhead & Co. There are five spark gaps made by two series of rods, the rods of each series being connected together by self-induction coils. The gaps are adjustable and decrease toward the terminals to which the instruments are connected, the last gap being small and made between two fine platinum points. The self-induction of the coils does not interfere with the ordinary current through the circuit, but chokes back a discharge of any magnitude, and forces it to escape through the air gaps. The major portion of a lightning discharge passes across the first gap while the remainder is filtered through the other gaps.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914–808.

title: LLM-LINKED
description: No insulator patented by Purves and Sinnott (1907) appears. The name Purves appears only in relation to Dr. W. L. Purves (associated with ophthalmic instruments like co148738) and David Purves (a patent boiler flue model, co8056508).

Maker/Donor: Made by Messrs. J. W. Albert. Lent by The Institution of Electrical Engineers.
Object entry information: This instrument, made in 1863, was invented by Philipp Reis of Frankfurt for the transmission and reception by electrical means of all kinds of sounds. Since it definitely succeeded in this, the invention is generally held to be the first electric telephone. / From his published work it appears that Reis fully understood the fundamental principles involved in the electrical transmission and reception of sounds, and although his apparatus was less perfect than that of later inventors, it was undoubtedly capable of transmitting articulate speech as well as musical sounds. / Reis named his apparatus the “Telephon.” He probably designed ten distinct forms of transmitter and four forms of receiver. The apparatus here shown embodies the final forms of each. The transmitter consists of a hollow cube of wood having a circular opening in the lid which is closed by an elastic membrane (pig's lesser intestine). Upon the centre of this membrane is glued a little plate of platinum, which is connected with one terminal by a thin metal strip. Upon the middle of the platinum plate rests a short platinum pencil fastened to the underside of an angular metal strip. At one end of this strip a platinum spike on the underside rests in a mercury cup while the other end rests upon a metal pillar connected with a second terminal. / On speaking into the mouthpiece of the instrument the membrane vibrates and produces loose-contact phenomena between the platinum plate and the pencil. That these were intended to give a following-contact and not a clean break seems likely from the inventor’s writings and from the design of his other transmitters, in all of which some form of following-contact is formed. / On the side of the resonating box a simple telegraph apparatus is placed for the purpose of supplementing the telephone communications. / The receiver consists of a resonating box on the top of which is placed a long solenoid wound on a wooden bobbin. Through the centre of this a steel knitting-needle is thrust. A hinged lid closes over the solenoid. / The changes in the magnetic state of the needle occasioned by the speech-varied current create vibrations which are communicated to the resonant box, the original sounds being reproduced with sufficient distinctness to be heard by anyone placing his ear to the box. (See “Philipp Reis,” by S. P. Thompson, 1883.)

Catalogue number: 95.
Object name: EARLY TELEPHONE RECEIVER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by A. A. Campbell Swinton, Esq., F.R.S. (Made by Mr. S. M. Yeates of Dublin).
Date of creation: 1865
Object entry information: This is a facsimile of a telephone receiver made in 1865 by Mr. S. M. Yeates of Dublin. It is an improvement on Reis's receiver, and has a reed armature fixed in proximity to the free ends of the core of a horseshoe electro-magnet.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1916–54.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 96.
Object name: BELL TRANSMITTER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: 1876
Object entry information: This represents one of the earliest instruments with which successful speech transmission was obtained. It is very similar to the transmitter exhibited by Bell at Philadelphia in 1876. / The diaphragm is of goldbeater’s skin and has at its centre a piece of cork to which is attached one end of a strip of soft iron. The other end of the strip is hinged in an iron frame carrying an electro-magnet, one of whose poles approaches nearly to the strip which vibrates with the diaphragm. / This apparatus was not a magnetic telephone pure and simple, for a battery of several cells was placed in the circuit.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914–817.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 98.
Object name: EARLY BELL TELEPHONE. Plate 8.
Maker/Donor: Patented by Prof. Alexander Graham Bell
Date of creation: 1876
Object entry information: This form of magnetic telephone, patented by Prof. Alexander Graham Bell in 1876, was one of the earliest to be brought into practical use. The instrument consists of a permanent horse-shoe magnet, having short coils mounted upon its poles, while in front of the coils is a thin iron disc or diaphragm carried by a block of wood, through which there is a hole communicating with an external mouth or ear-piece. The coils are joined in series, and connected by a line wire with those of a similar instrument, the circuit being completed by connecting one terminal at each end with the earth. Speech uttered into the mouth-piece of one of the instruments sets the diaphragm into a state of vibration, and its movements produce variations of the number of lines of magnetic force passing through the coils. Alternating currents, corresponding to the pitch, amplitude and timbre of the sound, are consequently induced, and are transmitted to the second instrument. On passing through the coils of the latter, these currents, by producing changes in the magnetisation, cause variations of the force with which the diaphragm is attracted. This is consequently made to repeat the movements of the first diaphragm, and the original sounds are reproduced. Each instrument is used alternately as a transmitting and as a receiver to reproduce the sounds. In modern telephony distinct instruments are employed for transmitting and receiving. The receivers generally used are similar in principle to those shown, but considerably modified in design; modern transmitters, however, are altogether different, phenomena of loose-contact being employed to impress audio-frequency modulations on the current from a battery.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1906-10.

Catalogue number: 100.
Object name: ORIGINAL HUGHES'S MICROPHONES.
Maker/Donor: Made by Prof. D. E. Hughes. Presented by the Executors of the late Mrs. Anna C. Hughes.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is a selection from the original apparatus made and used by Prof. Hughes in his experiments connected with the discovery of the microphone in 1878. (1) A microphone, consisting of three French nails, used by Prof. Hughes for making audible in a telephone the motion of insects imprisoned in a small gauze-covered box. (2) A microphone, consisting of wood charcoal blocks, pressed together by means of a spring.
Object/Inventory number: N/A.

The receivers generally used are similar in principle to those shown, but considerably modified in design; modern transmitters, however, are altogether different, phenomena of loose-contact being employed to impress audio-frequency modulations on the current from a battery.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 98.
Object name: EARLY BELL TELEPHONE. Plate 8.
Maker/Donor: Patented by Prof. Alexander Graham Bell
Date of creation: 1876
Object entry information: This form of magnetic telephone, patented by Prof. Alexander Graham Bell in 1876, was one of the earliest to be brought into practical use. The instrument consists of a permanent horse-shoe magnet, having short coils mounted upon its poles, while in front of the coils is a thin iron disc or diaphragm carried by a block of wood, through which there is a hole communicating with an external mouth or ear-piece. The coils are joined in series, and connected by a line wire with those of a similar instrument, the circuit being completed by connecting one terminal at each end with the earth. Speech uttered into the mouth-piece of one of the instruments sets the diaphragm into a state of vibration, and its movements produce variations of the number of lines of magnetic force passing through the coils. Alternating currents, corresponding to the pitch, amplitude and timbre of the sound, are consequently induced, and are transmitted to the second instrument. On passing through the coils of the latter, these currents, by producing changes in the magnetisation, cause variations of the force with which the diaphragm is attracted. This is consequently made to repeat the movements of the first diaphragm, and the original sounds are reproduced. Each instrument is used alternately as a transmitting and as a receiver to reproduce the sounds. In modern telephony distinct instruments are employed for transmitting and receiving. The receivers generally used are similar in principle to those shown, but considerably modified in design; modern transmitters, however, are altogether different, phenomena of loose-contact being employed to impress audio-frequency modulations on the current from a battery.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1906-10.

Maker/Donor: Made by Prof. D. E. Hughes. Presented by the Executors of the late Mrs. Anna C. Hughes.
Object entry information:
This is a further selection of the original apparatus made and used by Prof. Hughes in the experiments which led him from the discovery of the microphone in 1878 to the transmission and reception of wireless signals over a short distance in 1879.
A number of microphones designed and made by Prof. Hughes in 1878 and 1879 are exhibited:
(1) Carbon pencil microphones, invented by Prof. Hughes in 1878; each consists of a pencil of carbon supported with its ends in hollows in two small carbon blocks. Several examples of this type of microphone are exhibited with a number of pencils of various sizes and shapes.
(2) Microphones in which the pressure on the contacts is regulated by means of a spring. In two of the examples shown the spring acts through a pivoted lever, the contacts being, in one case, between three small blocks of pinewood charcoal and in the other between a piece of coke and a steel rod. In the third example, the contacts are between carbon pellets contained on a glass tube and acted on directly by a helical spring.
(3) Microphone consisting of two weighted carbon rods suspended by paper strips so that they lie horizontally, each in contact with two vertical carbon rods. There are thus four contacts in series. The microphone is mounted on a pinewood diaphragm.
(4) Granular microphones in which a very large number of contacts are obtained by passing the current through a tube containing a granulated substance. The substances most often used by Prof. Hughes were zinc and silver filings. Three examples are shown, the granules being contained in a quill, a glass tube and a hollow bamboo. This type of microphone was developed by Prof. Hughes without knowledge of the previous work of Edison.
Several types of microphones were used for detecting wireless signals. (See “Electrical Communication,” Part II, Cat. No. 1.)

Catalogue number: 102.
Object name: GRANULAR TRANSMITTER. Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General. Plate 10.
Maker/Donor: Patented by Mr. H. Hunnings; Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: 1878
Object entry information: The granular transmitter was patented by Mr. H. Hunnings in 1878, and was afterwards considerably modified.
The modified form shown consists of a carbon diaphragm and a carbon plate, the central portion of the intervening space being occupied with carbon granules. Its action depends on the varying electrical resistance, due to the varying pressure, produced by the sound vibrations. The whole is mounted in a porcelain frame provided with a mouth-piece.
(See Preece and Stubbs' “Manual of Telephony,” p. 81.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1911–53.

Maker/Donor: Presented by F. Faithfull Begg, Esq. Patented by Mr. L. J. Crossley in 1879.
Object entry information:
This is an early example of the application of Hughes's carbon pencil microphone, with multiple contact points, to purposes of telephone transmission.
It was patented by Mr. L. J. Crossley in 1879.
The instrument was adopted as the standard transmitter by the Post Office, and was also largely used by telephone companies. Early in 1879, a Crossley transmitter was used for the transmission of a service from the Square Congregational Chapel, Halifax, to Manchester, over a route of 36 miles. The singing, organ music and sermon were distinctly heard. As one of the first successful experiments in distance telephony, it was regarded as a remarkable achievement.
Four pencils of carbon, smaller in diameter at the ends than in the central area, and arranged approximately in the form of a rectangle and fit loosely into holes, drilled in carbon blocks, fixed to a thin deal diaphragm. Connecting wires are taken from two opposite corners of the rectangle, so that the eight variable resistance contacts are arranged four in series, in two parallel circuits.

Catalogue number: 105.
Object name: EARLY TELEPHONE TRANSMITTER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by L. B. Turner, Esq.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This interesting transmitter was found, with other portions of a disused telephone, fixed to a wall of a house in Cambridge. The mouth-piece was in communication with the hollow wooden block, air pressure variations due to speech affecting equally two non-metallic membranes placed opposite each other and on either side of the orifice.
The membranes have metal centre-pieces, and their motion induces speech currents in the neighbouring magnet-windings. The instrument in fact comprises two receivers of the Stanhope type used inversely, as the early Bell instruments were used, to act as transmitters.
The receiver used in conjunction with this transmitter was also of the Stanhope or membrane pattern.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1925–511.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 107.
Object name: MICROPHONIC TELEPHONE TRANSMITTER. Plate 10.
Maker/Donor: Made and Presented by A. A. Campbell Swinton, Esq., F.R.S.
Date of creation: 1884 (Patented)
Object entry information: This transmitter was patented by Mr. Campbell Swinton in 1884. A diaphragm is dispensed with, and the vibrations of the voice act upon a number of wooden tongues, which are freely suspended at one end and carry carbon contacts at the other.
In the example shown six tongues are suspended by tapes from a cross-member. At their lower ends strips of carbon are attached, and these press lightly on small carbon blocks, cylindrical in shape, which are placed at right angles to the strips. Each strip makes electrical contact with two adjacent carbon blocks, and alternate blocks throughout the length of the transmitter are connected with a brass which carries a terminal strip.
The arrangement is such that there are 12 variable contacts, arranged two in series in six parallel circuits. The mechanism is mounted on a board hinged at the top so that its inclination to the vertical, and consequently the pressure of the contacts upon each other, may be adjusted.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1916–48.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 108.
Object name: EXPERIMENTAL TELEPHONE TRANSMITTER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by A. A. Campbell Swinton, Esq., F.R.S.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This transmitter, which is very similar to that employed in the telephone set shown under Cat. No. 124, was patented by Mr. Campbell Swinton in 1884 and 1885.
Fourteen carbon rods are strung on a wire stretched across a light bent wire frame, and at their lower ends rest against a stout carbon rod placed across the framework and insulated from it. There are thus 14 variable resistance contacts placed in parallel circuits. The frame is supported on a larger frame by four rubber bands, the object of which is to prevent other vibrations than those of the speaker's voice from affecting the microphone.
No diaphragm is used, the vibrations of the voice acting directly upon the carbon rods.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1916–50.

The receiver used in conjunction with this transmitter was also of the Stanhope or membrane pattern.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1925–511.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 107.
Object name: MICROPHONIC TELEPHONE TRANSMITTER. Plate 10.
Maker/Donor: Made and Presented by A. A. Campbell Swinton, Esq., F.R.S.
Date of creation: 1884 (Patented)
Object entry information: This transmitter was patented by Mr. Campbell Swinton in 1884. A diaphragm is dispensed with, and the vibrations of the voice act upon a number of wooden tongues, which are freely suspended at one end and carry carbon contacts at the other.
In the example shown six tongues are suspended by tapes from a cross-member. At their lower ends strips of carbon are attached, and these press lightly on small carbon blocks, cylindrical in shape, which are placed at right angles to the strips. Each strip makes electrical contact with two adjacent carbon blocks, and alternate blocks throughout the length of the transmitter are connected with a brass which carries a terminal strip.
The arrangement is such that there are 12 variable contacts, arranged two in series in six parallel circuits. The mechanism is mounted on a board hinged at the top so that its inclination to the vertical, and consequently the pressure of the contacts upon each other, may be adjusted.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1916–48.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 108.
Object name: EXPERIMENTAL TELEPHONE TRANSMITTER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by A. A. Campbell Swinton, Esq., F.R.S.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This transmitter, which is very similar to that employed in the telephone set shown under Cat. No. 124, was patented by Mr. Campbell Swinton in 1884 and 1885.
Fourteen carbon rods are strung on a wire stretched across a light bent wire frame, and at their lower ends rest against a stout carbon rod placed across the framework and insulated from it. There are thus 14 variable resistance contacts placed in parallel circuits. The frame is supported on a larger frame by four rubber bands, the object of which is to prevent other vibrations than those of the speaker's voice from affecting the microphone.
No diaphragm is used, the vibrations of the voice acting directly upon the carbon rods.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1916–50.
