Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 110.
Object name: DECKERT TRANSMITTER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: patented in 1889-91 by Mr. W. Deckert
Object entry information: Plate 10. This transmitter, of the granular type, was patented in 1889-91 by Mr. W. Deckert, and is sometimes known as the “Hunnings Cone” transmitter. It consists of a carbon plate, faced with a number of small square-based pyramids, in front of which there is a carbon diaphragm, and the space between the two is occupied with loose carbon granules. The tips of the central pyramids are removed and tufts of silk are attached. These damp the vibrations of the diaphragm, and also prevent short-circuiting between the latter and the plate. A woollen ring is mounted on the inner surface of the diaphragm, while the outer face is varnished; the diaphragm is protected by gauze wire, no mouth-piece being provided.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1911-54.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 111.
Object name: COLLIER TELEPHONE RECEIVER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: patented by Mr. A. T. Collier in 1889–90.
Object entry information: Plate 10. This receiver, which possesses some original features, was patented by Mr. A. T. Collier in 1889–90. At each end of a single core electro-magnet a diaphragm is held in position by a cap, which carries a soft iron pole piece. The case containing these parts is formed by the poles of a strong permanent horse-shoe magnet, which are clamped between the diaphragms and the ends of the coil. The ear-piece, situated at the side, communicates by means of holes arranged round a central cone, with the air spaces between the diaphragms and the ends of the coil. The example shown has been sectioned. (See Preece and Stubbs’s “Manual of Telephony,” p. 53.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1911-113.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 112.
Object name: DOUBLE POLE BELL RECEIVERS.
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: replaced the single-pole pattern in 1890
Object entry information: Plate 10. These are early double-pole receivers of the type which in 1890 replaced the single-pole pattern. (See Cat. No. 99.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913-206.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 113.
Object name: MIX AND GENEST TELEPHONE TRANSMITTER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General. Patented by Mr. H. Oppenheimer.
Date of creation: Patented in 1900 and 1902.
Object entry information: This transmitter, of the granular carbon type, was patented by Mr. H. Oppenheimer in 1900 and 1902. A carbon diaphragm is used in conjunction with a carbon back-plate, which is double-lipped to contain the granules and is mounted on a flat spring fixed at one end only. A piece of cloth surrounds the gap between the diaphragm and back-plate, and a small tuft of flannel fixed at the centre of the back-plate serves to damp the vibrations of the diaphragm. A circular piece of paper, faced with tinfoil, is stuck to the centre of the carbon diaphragm as a protection. A back-plate arm forms one side of a circular metal case which contains the microphone. The second terminal is formed by an adjustable platinum-tipped screw, carried in a projecting arm, which presses on a spring at the back of the case. This spring is connected with the spring carrying the back-plate, and is protected from contact with the case by insulation. An earlier form of Mix and Genest transmitter is shown with a wall set (Cat. No. 127).
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1915-238.

The case containing these parts is formed by the poles of a strong permanent horse-shoe magnet, which are clamped between the diaphragms and the ends of the coil. The ear-piece, situated at the side, communicates by means of holes arranged round a central cone, with the air spaces between the diaphragms and the ends of the coil. The example shown has been sectioned. (See Preece and Stubbs’s “Manual of Telephony,” p. 53.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1911-113.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 113.
Object name: MIX AND GENEST TELEPHONE TRANSMITTER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General. Patented by Mr. H. Oppenheimer.
Date of creation: Patented in 1900 and 1902.
Object entry information: This transmitter, of the granular carbon type, was patented by Mr. H. Oppenheimer in 1900 and 1902. A carbon diaphragm is used in conjunction with a carbon back-plate, which is double-lipped to contain the granules and is mounted on a flat spring fixed at one end only. A piece of cloth surrounds the gap between the diaphragm and back-plate, and a small tuft of flannel fixed at the centre of the back-plate serves to damp the vibrations of the diaphragm. A circular piece of paper, faced with tinfoil, is stuck to the centre of the carbon diaphragm as a protection. A back-plate arm forms one side of a circular metal case which contains the microphone. The second terminal is formed by an adjustable platinum-tipped screw, carried in a projecting arm, which presses on a spring at the back of the case. This spring is connected with the spring carrying the back-plate, and is protected from contact with the case by insulation. An earlier form of Mix and Genest transmitter is shown with a wall set (Cat. No. 127).
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1915-238.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 110.
Object name: DECKERT TRANSMITTER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: patented in 1889-91 by Mr. W. Deckert
Object entry information: Plate 10. This transmitter, of the granular type, was patented in 1889-91 by Mr. W. Deckert, and is sometimes known as the “Hunnings Cone” transmitter. It consists of a carbon plate, faced with a number of small square-based pyramids, in front of which there is a carbon diaphragm, and the space between the two is occupied with loose carbon granules. The tips of the central pyramids are removed and tufts of silk are attached. These damp the vibrations of the diaphragm, and also prevent short-circuiting between the latter and the plate. A woollen ring is mounted on the inner surface of the diaphragm, while the outer face is varnished; the diaphragm is protected by gauze wire, no mouth-piece being provided.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1911-54.

Object entry information: This is one of the first subscribers' sets supplied by the Edison Telephone Co., which commenced operations in this country in 1879. The main features of the instrument, the carbon transmitter and electromotograph (see adjacent exhibit), were patented by Edison in 1877. The transmitter, used—the parent of all modern transmitters—consists essentially of a button of soft carbon, about 3/8 in. in diameter, placed between two brass discs. One of these discs has a small glass centre, against which presses a brass stud fixed to the sheet iron diaphragm. The two brass discs are connected with the terminals of the instrument. Speech into the mouth-piece causes the diaphragm to vibrate, and produces variations in the resistance of the button and corresponding variations in the current transmitted through the line. The receiver, or “electromotograph,” has a small chalk cylinder, which is kept moistened with potassium iodide, and which is rotated by a handle through worm gearing. A brass diaphragm carries at its centre a brass strip spring, holding a platinum contact piece, which presses lightly against the chalk cylinder, the spring being tangential to the cylinder. The amount of friction exerted on the platinum contact by the rotating cylinder varies with the current passing to it from the sender, and this causes the spring and diaphragm to vibrate. The vibrations are damped by an indiarubber pad, the pressure of which against the back of the spring may be adjusted by a screw. This receiver, although loud and clear, required too much attention, and was abandoned after the amalgamation of the Edison and Bell Companies in 1880. Within the box, on which the transmitter is fitted, is an induction coil with three windings, and the mechanism seen above the box is a relay for the bell. There are also two keys, one for ringing and the other for closing the local microphone circuit. When the ringing key is up, the relay and the “tertiary” of the induction coil are connected in series between line and earth. Depressing the relay key breaks this connection and substitutes the battery between the line and earth. The microphone circuit is made up of the microphone, two cells of the battery, microphone key and primary of the induction coil. The tertiary coil acts as secondary for transmission and primary for receiving.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 116.
Object name: WALL TELEPHONE SET.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is a wall instrument of an early type, with Blake transmitter and a trembler bell. No receiver is shown fitted. The transmitter was patented by Mr. F. Blake in 1879, and was the subject of an action between the Edison and the Bell Telephone Companies, the former of which claimed that the instrument infringed their patent (see telephone set, Cat. No. 114). In 1880 the two companies amalgamated and became the United Telephone Co., and the action was withdrawn. A sheet-iron diaphragm is used, against which presses a platinum contact mounted on a light flexible spring. The other end of this platinum contact presses lightly against a carbon button supported on another flexible spring. The springs are insulated from one another, and both mounted on a lever pivoted at the top and able to swing towards or away from the diaphragm. The pressures of the contacts are regulated by a screw which engages a slanting surface on the lower end of this lever. This telephone set, in common with most of the earlier instruments, was at first used in conjunction with one-line wire only, the return circuit being through the earth. The instrument has a switch operated by the receiver.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914–769.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 119.
Object name: GOWER-BELL TELEPHONES.
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: Patented in 1880.
Object entry information: Owing to the very small electric currents developed in the magnetic telephone as arranged by Graham Bell (Inv. 1906–10), it could be used efficiently as a transmitter over comparatively short distances only. Transmitters were consequently introduced in which currents from batteries were utilised, and the acoustical effects were employed to produce variations of the resistances of the circuits. Undulating currents were thus obtained, which, by means of magnetic receivers, were made to reproduce the exciting sounds. At first the transmitter and its battery were placed in circuit with the line wire and the distant receiver, and as the variations in resistance produced in the transmitter were small compared with the total resistance, the changes in the current were correspondingly small. This difficulty was overcome by using an induction coil, the primary of which was in circuit with the transmitter and battery, while the secondary was connected with the line. T. A. Edison in 1877 constructed an instrument of this type, the action of which depended upon changes in the resistance of carbon with variations of pressure, while, in 1878, Prof. D. E. Hughes introduced his "microphone" (Cat. Nos. 100 and 101), which utilised the variation of the resistance of substances in loose contact placed in the neighbourhood of the sounds to be reproduced. Carbon was found to be the most suitable material, and many forms of carbon transmitters embodying the principle of Hughes's apparatus are now employed. The instruments shown are of a type which was used in the British Post Office, in which a carbon transmitter, patented by Mr. F. A. Gower in 1880, is employed. This consists of eight carbon pencils, supported between eight carbon blocks and one central block, all the blocks being recessed to receive loosely the reduced ends of the pencils. Four of the outside blocks are connected by means of a copper strip with one terminal of the battery, while the remaining four are connected, through the primary of an induction coil, with the other. The blocks are mounted upon a thin deal board, which constitutes the diaphragm and is enclosed in a wooden casing fitted with a porcelain mouth-piece.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 119.
Object name: GOWER-BELL TELEPHONES.
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: Patented in 1880.
Object entry information: Owing to the very small electric currents developed in the magnetic telephone as arranged by Graham Bell (Inv. 1906–10), it could be used efficiently as a transmitter over comparatively short distances only. Transmitters were consequently introduced in which currents from batteries were utilised, and the acoustical effects were employed to produce variations of the resistances of the circuits. Undulating currents were thus obtained, which, by means of magnetic receivers, were made to reproduce the exciting sounds. At first the transmitter and its battery were placed in circuit with the line wire and the distant receiver, and as the variations in resistance produced in the transmitter were small compared with the total resistance, the changes in the current were correspondingly small. This difficulty was overcome by using an induction coil, the primary of which was in circuit with the transmitter and battery, while the secondary was connected with the line. T. A. Edison in 1877 constructed an instrument of this type, the action of which depended upon changes in the resistance of carbon with variations of pressure, while, in 1878, Prof. D. E. Hughes introduced his "microphone" (Cat. Nos. 100 and 101), which utilised the variation of the resistance of substances in loose contact placed in the neighbourhood of the sounds to be reproduced. Carbon was found to be the most suitable material, and many forms of carbon transmitters embodying the principle of Hughes's apparatus are now employed. The instruments shown are of a type which was used in the British Post Office, in which a carbon transmitter, patented by Mr. F. A. Gower in 1880, is employed. This consists of eight carbon pencils, supported between eight carbon blocks and one central block, all the blocks being recessed to receive loosely the reduced ends of the pencils. Four of the outside blocks are connected by means of a copper strip with one terminal of the battery, while the remaining four are connected, through the primary of an induction coil, with the other. The blocks are mounted upon a thin deal board, which constitutes the diaphragm and is enclosed in a wooden casing fitted with a porcelain mouth-piece.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1908–187.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 123.
Object name: THOMPSON VALVE TELEPHONE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by the States of Jersey.
Date of creation: Invented in 1884.
Object entry information: This telephone was invented by Prof. S. P. Thompson, F.R.S., and was used by the “New Telephone Co.,” which in 1884 made an unsuccessful attempt to compete with the United Telephone Co., owners of the patents of Bell and Edison. The transmitter consists of a conical piece of carbon, supported vertically by three carbon points fitting loosely into holes situated on the largest circumference of the cone. On speaking into the transmitter, the valve formed by this carbon cone became partially unseated, and produced variations of resistance due to imperfect contact. The receiver is of the membrane type.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–437.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 124.
Object name: TABLE TELEPHONE SET.
Maker/Donor: Presented by A. A. Campbell Swinton, Esq., F.R.S.
Date of creation: Patented in 1885.
Object entry information: This instrument, which was patented by the donor in 1885, is interesting from the fact that the multiple pencil carbon transmitter is not placed beneath a diaphragm, as is usually the case, but is directly exposed to the sound waves set up by the speaker’s voice. The receiver is of the membrane type.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1916–51.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 125.
Object name: ADER TELEPHONE SETS. (2 Instruments.)
Maker/Donor: Made by the Société Industrielle des Téléphones.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: These instruments are fitted with Ader transmitters and receivers. One of the latter is partially sectioned. The transmitter is of the carbon pencil type fitted to a thin deal board, which acts as a diaphragm. The receiver is a double-pole instrument. Underneath the ear-cap a ring of soft iron is let into the metal cover, for the purpose of concentrating the magnetic flux on the iron diaphragm. A press-button is provided for battery ringing.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913–499.

Object entry information: These instruments are of the office or household type, and are fitted with shot carbon transmitters, double-pole receivers, trembler bells and press-buttons. One of the sets has been partially sectioned.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1912–349.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 127.
Object name: WALL TELEPHONE SET.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: Patented in 1887 and 1891.
Object entry information: This telephone set has a Mix and Genest transmitter of the carbon pencil type, made under the patents of Mr. W. Genest in 1887 and Mr. H. Oppenheimer in 1891. Two carbon pencils are used, the reduced ends of which enter large-sized holes in two rectangular carbon blocks, which are fixed to the diaphragm. Between the pencils, and pivoted in the two carbon blocks, is a bridge which carries on its lower side a flat brush of stiff bristles which bears against the pencils, so that their ends are always in contact with the surface of the holes in the carbon blocks. The brush also prevents independent rolling motion of the pencils, which is one of the probable causes of a jarring noise being heard in the receiver when a carbon pencil microphone is used in a vertical position. The lever with which the receiver (not shown) is hung acts as a switch, and when depressed with the receiver in place the bell circuit is connected with the line. On removing the receiver, the lever springs up, breaking the bell connection and placing the transmitter and receiver in circuit. A ringing key is situated on the left-hand side of the box. (See “ A Manual of Telephony,” by Preece and Stubbs.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1915–201.

Object entry information: This instrument, which was patented by the donor in 1885, is interesting from the fact that the multiple pencil carbon transmitter is not placed beneath a diaphragm, as is usually the case, but is directly exposed to the sound waves set up by the speaker’s voice. The receiver is of the membrane type.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1916–51.

Catalogue number: 125.
Object name: ADER TELEPHONE SETS. (2 Instruments.)
Maker/Donor: Made by the Société Industrielle des Téléphones.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: These instruments are fitted with Ader transmitters and receivers. One of the latter is partially sectioned. The transmitter is of the carbon pencil type fitted to a thin deal board, which acts as a diaphragm. The receiver is a double-pole instrument. Underneath the ear-cap a ring of soft iron is let into the metal cover, for the purpose of concentrating the magnetic flux on the iron diaphragm. A press-button is provided for battery ringing.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913–499.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 126.
Object name: TWO WALL TELEPHONES.
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: These instruments are of the office or household type, and are fitted with shot carbon transmitters, double-pole receivers, trembler bells and press-buttons. One of the sets has been partially sectioned.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 127.
Object name: WALL TELEPHONE SET.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: Patented in 1887 and 1891.
Object entry information: This telephone set has a Mix and Genest transmitter of the carbon pencil type, made under the patents of Mr. W. Genest in 1887 and Mr. H. Oppenheimer in 1891. Two carbon pencils are used, the reduced ends of which enter large-sized holes in two rectangular carbon blocks, which are fixed to the diaphragm. Between the pencils, and pivoted in the two carbon blocks, is a bridge which carries on its lower side a flat brush of stiff bristles which bears against the pencils, so that their ends are always in contact with the surface of the holes in the carbon blocks. The brush also prevents independent rolling motion of the pencils, which is one of the probable causes of a jarring noise being heard in the receiver when a carbon pencil microphone is used in a vertical position. The lever with which the receiver (not shown) is hung acts as a switch, and when depressed with the receiver in place the bell circuit is connected with the line. On removing the receiver, the lever springs up, breaking the bell connection and placing the transmitter and receiver in circuit. A ringing key is situated on the left-hand side of the box. (See “ A Manual of Telephony,” by Preece and Stubbs.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1915–201.

Object entry information: This telephone was invented by Prof. S. P. Thompson, F.R.S., and was used by the “New Telephone Co.,” which in 1884 made an unsuccessful attempt to compete with the United Telephone Co., owners of the patents of Bell and Edison. The transmitter consists of a conical piece of carbon, supported vertically by three carbon points fitting loosely into holes situated on the largest circumference of the cone. On speaking into the transmitter, the valve formed by this carbon cone became partially unseated, and produced variations of resistance due to imperfect contact. The receiver is of the membrane type.

title: Wall instrument with Mix and Genext's carbon trans
description: Wall instrument with Mix and Genest's carbon transmitter (brush damper)

Object entry information: This small switchboard provides accommodation for ten telephone circuits within the same building. This and other similar systems are extensively used both for industrial and domestic purposes. Each circuit terminates on the same numbered stud on the switch at every station, except the “home” station, where it is connected direct to the telephone. A separate speaking battery is provided for each telephone, but a common battery furnishes energy for signalling over the whole system.

Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914–774.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 129.
Object name: WALL TELEPHONE WITH STROWGER AUTOMATIC DIAL.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Automatic Telephone Manufacturing Co., Liverpool.
Date of creation: Made in 1900.
Object entry information: A. B. Strowger, the inventor of the first successful automatic telephone exchange, filed his original application for a patent in America in 1889. The earliest public exchange worked on this system was opened at La Porte, Ind., in 1892. The instrument exhibited is an example of the early type of wall telephones arranged for connection to a Strowger automatic telephone exchange. A complex dialling switch was used with each instrument, and the case is left partially open to show the interior portion of this. In modern practice, the apparatus at the subscribers' premises is of a much more simple character. Situated at the base of the dialling switch are the coils of a magneto bell, the two gongs of which are on the front of the case. A magneto generator is fitted inside the box as hand-ringing was necessary with this instrument. In modern exchanges machine-ringing is general. The lower part of the case contained the primary cells required for the speaking circuit before the central battery system was adapted to automatic telephone transmission. A. B. Strowger was an undertaker in Kansas City, and frequently used the telephone for business purposes. This originated his desire to substitute machine operation for manual operation. Between the years 1892 and 1902 progress was slow, but with the adoption of new inventions and improvements the automatic telephone extended its influence in all parts of the world and many of the largest exchanges are now worked on the automatic principle. The first public automatic telephone exchange in this country was installed at Epsom in 1912. Other systems of automatic telephone exchanges are the Siemens, the Western Electric, &c. (See also Cat. No. 130.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914–560.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 130.
Object name: STROWGER AUTOMATIC TELEPHONE WALL SET. Plate 12.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Institution of Electrical Engineers.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This instrument is of a later type than that shown under Cat. No. 129. It has no hand generator or primary cells, and was used on an exchange where machine-ringing and central battery conditions for speaking were available. (See also Cat. No. 129.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–256.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 131.
Object name: INTERCOMMUNICATION SWITCH FOR FOUR LINES.
Maker/Donor: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This switch is one of a type supplied for office use by the National Telephone Co. prior to 1912. The indicators are of the mechanically restored pattern in which the shutter, having fallen to indicate a call, is replaced in the normal position when a plug is inserted in the corresponding jack.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914–771.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 132.
Object name: TELEPHONE SWITCHBOARD. MILITARY SIGNAL SERVICE TYPE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Imperial War Museum.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This switchboard accommodates 30 telephone circuits and one operator's position. The magneto system of working is adopted. Each circuit terminates on a separate peg, and is teed to a five-point jack, the inner springs of which are connected to a drop indicator, so that any line can be picked up either at the peg or jack. Any two lines are connected by putting the called number's peg into the calling number's jack. The same indicators serve for both calling and clearing.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–629.

A complex dialling switch was used with each instrument, and the case is left partially open to show the interior portion of this. In modern practice, the apparatus at the subscribers' premises is of a much more simple character. Situated at the base of the dialling switch are the coils of a magneto bell, the two gongs of which are on the front of the case. A magneto generator is fitted inside the box as hand-ringing was necessary with this instrument. In modern exchanges machine-ringing is general. The lower part of the case contained the primary cells required for the speaking circuit before the central battery system was adapted to automatic telephone transmission. A. B. Strowger was an undertaker in Kansas City, and frequently used the telephone for business purposes. This originated his desire to substitute machine operation for manual operation. Between the years 1892 and 1902 progress was slow, but with the adoption of new inventions and improvements the automatic telephone extended its influence in all parts of the world and many of the largest exchanges are now worked on the automatic principle. The first public automatic telephone exchange in this country was installed at Epsom in 1912. Other systems of automatic telephone exchanges are the Siemens, the Western Electric, &c. (See also Cat. No. 130.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914–560.

Object name: WORKING MODEL OF THE AUTOMATIC TELEPHONE SYSTEM FOR THE LONDON AREA.
Maker/Donor: Lent by the General Post Office.
Object entry information: The problem of linking up very large area by means of automatic telephone exchanges is naturally an extremely complex one. Means must be provided whereby a subscriber on any automatic exchange may connect himself with any subscriber on his own or any other exchange, and the connection must be made in such a manner as to make the most economical use of lines and automatic switches. Moreover, during the period of transition which must elapse before the whole system has been converted to automatic working, special apparatus must be provided to deal with calls between the existing manual exchanges and the new automatic exchanges. After a prolonged study of the problem, the British Post Office Authorities have decided that the system to be installed in the London Area shall be based on the well-known Step-by-Step system, with the addition of the important “Director” principle. The function of the Director is to receive and store the subscriber’s call in its original form, and to proceed to send it out into the exchange switching mechanism, translated into any trains of impulses which may be required by the existing lay-out of junction routes and switching centres. Having steered the call through, link by link, to the line of the required subscriber, the director disconnects itself from the line and becomes available for other calls. Another important feature of the system is the Coder Call Indicator. This switchboard is the connecting link between a subscriber on an automatic exchange and a subscriber served from a manual exchange. It is a fine example of engineering skill, permitting impulses received from the automatic subscriber to be translated by the Director to be reproduced in the manual exchange in the form of an illuminated display of the required number. For traffic in the opposite direction various methods may be adopted, one of which—the use of cordless “B” positions—is included in this exhibit. The model, which was originally constructed for the British Empire Exhibition of 1924, is probably for its size the most complex mechanism extant. Six exchange switching centres are represented, access to these being given by a number of automatic telephones included in the exhibit. During the hours when the model is shown in operation, visitors may make test calls with these instruments, and may trace their progress through the various units and observe the manner in which calls from one automatic exchange to another, or between a manual and an automatic exchange, are dealt with.

Object entry information: and as early as 1879 a patent Instruments constructed Americans for an automatic switching device. were shown at the Paris Exhibition in 1881, but under the patent defects in the system precluded its use as a substitute for manual operation. The first successful attempt at machine telephone switching on the part of a British engineer was that of Mr. D. Sinclair, who in 1883 patented a semi-automatic device which dispensed with an operator at a branch exchange and provided for the control of calls from the distant central exchange where an operator was in attendance. A set of this apparatus is shown under Cat. No. 135. A working model of the latest automatic equipment which is to be installed in the London telephone area has recently been received by the Museum, and forms the central feature of the section.

description: No working model of the London system lent by the GPO in 1924 appears. The sources contain a "Demonstration set of Automatic Telephone Equipment" (co33726) and a "model of Automatic Telephone Exchange" (co48221), but neither entry confirms the specific "London Area" context or the 1924 loan date. Components from the first London Director exchange (e.g., co33563) are listed, but not the model itself.

Object entry information: This was used in the early days of telephony (about 1880) to obtain privacy, before the introduction of silence cabinets. It consists of a box with an elliptical hole in one side, around the edge of which there is a hollow indiarubber ring. When the apparatus was used the ring was inflated with air and formed a cushion for the speaker's face.

Catalogue number: [134]
Object name: [TELEPHONE REPEATERS OR TRANSLATORS.]
Maker/Donor: [Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.]
Date of creation: [N/A]
Object entry information: [These instruments, which are essentially transformers, were designed for the purpose of enabling a loop telephone circuit to be joined to a single-wire extension without seriously degrading the efficiency of the loop. The apparatus is now seldom used in that capacity, as few single-wire telephone circuits exist, but instruments of very similar construction are utilised for other telephone services. The term "telephone repeater" is now generally applied to thermionic valve equipment at an intermediate station on a telephone circuit.]
Object/Inventory number: [Inv. 1914-787, 796, 810-1 and 1915-245.]

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: [135]
Object name: [SINCLAIR'S LINE SELECTOR.]
Maker/Donor: [Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.]
Date of creation: [1886]
Object entry information: [This instrument, invented by Mr. D. Sinclair, represents the first attempt to provide an automatic telephone exchange in Great Britain. It was installed at Coatbridge, near Glasgow, in 1886, ten years before the first automatic exchange was set up in America. The apparatus consists of a step-by-step sender and a six-line switchboard with earth-return circuits. The step-by-step sender was employed at a central exchange to transmit currents to the automatic instrument which was placed in the branch exchange. This instrument was provided with a clockwork and electro-magnetic arrangement actuated by the incoming currents, which completed one of six circuits according to the position taken up by a rotating arm. The subscribers were connected in these circuits and a ringing current was afterwards sent out from the central exchange.]
Object/Inventory number: [Inv. 1914-786.]

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: [136]
Object name: [TELEPHONE CALL METER.]
Maker/Donor: [N/A]
Date of creation: [N/A]
Object entry information: [This instrument is used at the telephone exchange to register the number of effective calls originated by the subscriber on whose circuit it is fixed. A pawl and ratchet arrangement is operated by electrical means from the switchboard when the meter key is depressed by the operator controlling the call.]
Object/Inventory number: [Inv. 1913-678.]

Catalogue number: [138]
Object name: [ANGLO-BELGIAN SUBMARINE TELEPHONE CABLE, COIL LOADED.]
Maker/Donor: [Presented by Messrs. Siemens Bros. & Co., Ltd.]
Date of creation: [1911]
Object entry information: [This cable, designed to increase the speaking efficiency between this country and Belgium, was laid in 1911. The specimen shows a short length of cable on each side of a loading point. The conductors are four copper wires, each weighing 160 lb. per naut, insulated with an improved di-electric of the gutta-percha type, developed by the manufacturers of the cable, Messrs. Siemens Bros. This di-electric has much less leakance than ordinary gutta-percha at telephonic frequencies, and is especially suitable for coil-loaded submarine cables. The cable is arranged for superposing, and three speaking circuits are obtained from the two pairs of conductors.]
Object/Inventory number: [Inv. 1914-628.]

Object entry information: These instruments, which are essentially transformers, were designed for the purpose of enabling a loop telephone circuit to be joined to a single-wire extension without seriously degrading the efficiency of the loop. The apparatus is now seldom used in that capacity, as few single-wire telephone circuits exist, but instruments of very similar construction are utilised for other telephone services. The term "telephone repeater" is now generally applied to thermionic valve equipment at an intermediate station on a telephone circuit.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: [135]
Object name: [SINCLAIR'S LINE SELECTOR.]
Maker/Donor: [Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General.]
Date of creation: [1886]
Object entry information: [This instrument, invented by Mr. D. Sinclair, represents the first attempt to provide an automatic telephone exchange in Great Britain. It was installed at Coatbridge, near Glasgow, in 1886, ten years before the first automatic exchange was set up in America. The apparatus consists of a step-by-step sender and a six-line switchboard with earth-return circuits. The step-by-step sender was employed at a central exchange to transmit currents to the automatic instrument which was placed in the branch exchange. This instrument was provided with a clockwork and electro-magnetic arrangement actuated by the incoming currents, which completed one of six circuits according to the position taken up by a rotating arm. The subscribers were connected in these circuits and a ringing current was afterwards sent out from the central exchange.]
Object/Inventory number: [Inv. 1914-786.]

Object entry information: [This instrument, invented by Mr. D. Sinclair, represents the first attempt to provide an automatic telephone exchange in Great Britain. It was installed at Coatbridge, near Glasgow, in 1886, ten years before the first automatic exchange was set up in America. The apparatus consists of a step-by-step sender and a six-line switchboard with earth-return circuits. The step-by-step sender was employed at a central exchange to transmit currents to the automatic instrument which was placed in the branch exchange. This instrument was provided with a clockwork and electro-magnetic arrangement actuated by the incoming currents, which completed one of six circuits according to the position taken up by a rotating arm. The subscribers were connected in these circuits and a ringing current was afterwards sent out from the central exchange.]
Object/Inventory number: [Inv. 1914-786.]

Object entry information: [This instrument is used at the telephone exchange to register the number of effective calls originated by the subscriber on whose circuit it is fixed. A pawl and ratchet arrangement is operated by electrical means from the switchboard when the meter key is depressed by the operator controlling the call.]

Object name: [ANGLO-BELGIAN SUBMARINE TELEPHONE CABLE, COIL LOADED.]
Maker/Donor: [Presented by Messrs. Siemens Bros. & Co., Ltd.]
Date of creation: [1911]
Object entry information: [This cable, designed to increase the speaking efficiency between this country and Belgium, was laid in 1911. The specimen shows a short length of cable on each side of a loading point. The conductors are four copper wires, each weighing 160 lb. per naut, insulated with an improved di-electric of the gutta-percha type, developed by the manufacturers of the cable, Messrs. Siemens Bros. This di-electric has much less leakance than ordinary gutta-percha at telephonic frequencies, and is especially suitable for coil-loaded submarine cables. The cable is arranged for superposing, and three speaking circuits are obtained from the two pairs of conductors.]
Object/Inventory number: [Inv. 1914-628.]

Object name: THE TRANSMISSION OF PHOTOGRAPHS OVER LONG TELEPHONE LINES. Telephotographs Presented by The International Western Electric Company.
Object entry information: An examination of these telephotographs will show the degree of technical excellence to which the transmission of pictures over long telephone lines has now been carried. The system, which has been worked out over a period of several years by the American Telephone and Telegraph Co. and the Western Electric Co., represents the association of numerous modern inventions, such as the thermionic tube and the carrier-current transmission system, with the fundamental device known as a photo-electric cell. The simplicity of the method is such that a positive transparency, prepared by any photographer, may be sent while still wet over lines practically of any length in a few minutes, and after photographic development of the usual sort it is ready for newspaper or other reproduction. A photographic film, which is a transparent positive of the picture to be transmitted, is rolled inside a transparent cylinder. The cylinder and film are rotated at uniform speed, and at the same time advanced axially by a lead screw mechanism. During rotation a very fine beam of light passes through the transparent film and impinges on a sensitive photo-electric cell, which is mounted inside the cylinder. The intensity of the light impinging on the cell varies in accordance with the density of the film and corresponding variations of current are produced in the cell. These variations are employed to modulate a "carrier" current having a frequency of 1,300 cycles per second. The carrier current is transmitted over the line and at the receiving end its varying amplitudes control a light valve (a sensitive shutter device), which determines the amount of light impinging on a sensitised film attached to a cylinder similar to that employed at the transmitting end and rotating in synchronism with it. In this way the light and shade of the original picture are reproduced, but the received picture will be a negative instead of a positive. The motion of the cylinders at the two ends is synchronized by means of tuning forks controlling a 400-cycle synchronizing current, which is transmitted over the same circuit as the picture currents, the separation of the two currents being effected by means of electric wave filters.

description: The sources list "Telephotographs, three of four" which are described as having been "transmitted over the telephone lines". This matches the description of the telephotographs presented to show the technical excellence of picture transmission.
